PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. The amyloid protein is made up of fibrils that can be seen by staining. It can be present in any part of the body, but most commonly it is deposited in the heart, kidneys, liver, spleen, nervous system, and gastrointestinal tract. 2. Cardiac amyloidosis occurs when amyloid deposits form in the heart. This condition is often first noticed during a routine checkup when an abnormal heart sound is heard. It can occur at any age but is most common in people over 50. 3. People with cardiac amyloidosis may not have any symptoms, or they may have symptoms related to their heart condition. 4. A diagnosis of cardiac amyloidosis is based on a combination of the patient's medical history and test results. The most common tests used to diagnose cardiac amyloidosis are echocardiogram, electrocardiogram (EKG), and cardiac MRI. 5. Treatment is aimed at slowing the heart rate and reducing the workload on the heart. Medicines that may be used include beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, and digoxin. 6. Surgery may be used to treat specific problems such as abnormal heart rhythms. 7. The goal of treatment is to relieve symptoms and prevent heart failure. People with cardiac amyloidosis usually do not live long, but treatment may help people live longer.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1:
1. Migraine with aura; 2. Migraine without aura; 3. Status migrainosus; 4. Chronic migraine; 5. Migraine with brainstem involvement; 6. Complicated migraine

Introduction: Migraine is a common and debilitating primary headache disorder, affecting approximately 15% of women and 6% of men over a one year period. It is characterised by recurrent episodes of throbbing head pain, usually lasting 4-72 hours, and associated with nausea, photophobia and phonophobia. Migraine can be classified as either with or without aura. Aura can present as visual, sensory or motor symptoms, and can precede or coincide with the headache phase. Chronic migraine is diagnosed when migraine headache occurs on 15 or more days per month for more than three months. In this review, we focus on clinical studies that have investigated specific migraine treatments for the different migraine conditions described above. Migraine with aura; The pathophysiology of aura is not fully understood, but it is thought to arise from slowly spreading neuronal hyperexcitability and/or depressed activity, affecting visual, sensory and motor pathways. Migraine aura can be classified as typical or atypical. Typical aura consists of a monocular visual aura, which may progress to a full hemianopic visual field defect, and/or homonymous hemisensory, and/or hemimotor symptoms. Atypical aura consists of non-typical aura symptoms, including speech disturbances, vertigo, clumsiness, and/or brainstem symptoms. Migraine without aura; In those patients in whom aura features are not present, the pathophysiology of migraine is less well understood. It is thought that the headache phase may arise as a result of neurogenic inflammation and/or dysfunction of the trigeminovascular system. Status migrainosus; In this review, we also consider the treatments for patients with status migrainosus, a severe, debilitating migraine that does not resolve despite the use of usual acute treatments for migraine. Chron

For example, the triptans are especially effective for migraine with aura, while the dopamine receptor antagonist metoclopramide is especially effective for migraine that is accompanied by nausea and vomiting.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. Thyroid hormone regulates metabolism--the way the body uses energy--and affects nearly every organ in the body. Without enough thyroid hormone, many of the body's functions slow down.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Hypothyroidism may be due to congenital (born with it) or acquired (something that has happened to cause it to start later in life). 2. Most people with hypothyroidism are born with the condition and have no symptoms until later in life. 3. Hypothyroidism is more common in women than men. 4. Some causes of acquired hypothyroidism include thyroiditis, which is inflammation of the thyroid gland, and thyroid surgery. 5. Symptoms of hypothyroidism include feeling tired, gaining weight, constipation, having dry skin, and having mental and physical slowness. 6. In order to diagnose hypothyroidism, blood tests are done to measure the levels of thyroid hormones. 7. Hypothyroidism is treated with thyroid hormone replacement pills. 8. Most people do very well on this treatment and feel much better after starting it.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. Thyroid hormone regulates metabolism—the way the body uses energy—and affects nearly every organ in the body. Without enough thyroid hormone, many of the body's functions slow down. Hypothyroidism is often called underactive thyroid. Hypothyroidism may be due to:   - Hashimoto's disease—an autoimmune disorder in which the immune system attacks the thyroid gland   - Congenital hypothyroidism—hypothyroidism that is present at birth. It is usually caused by an inherited condition.   - Hypopituitarism—a condition in which the pituitary gland does not make enough thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). TSH is a hormone that tells the thyroid gland to make thyroid hormone.   - Radioactive iodine treatment for hyperthyroidism—treatment that involves taking a small dose of radioactive iodine, which destroys some of the thyroid gland tissue. Over time, the remaining thyroid tissue makes more thyroid hormone.   - Some medicines, such as amiodarone, lithium, and iodides   - An overactive thyroid gland that has been treated with radioactive iodine   - Certain chemicals, including polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and dioxin
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. Thyroid hormone regulates metabolism—the way the body uses energy—and affects nearly every organ in the body. Without enough thyroid hormone, many of the body's functions slow down. 2. Common causes of hypothyroidism include Hashimoto's disease, thyroiditis, thyroid surgery, radiation treatment, and certain medications. Hashimoto's disease is an autoimmune disorder that causes the thyroid to become underactive. Thyroiditis is an inflammation of the thyroid gland, which can occur after pregnancy. 3. Symptoms of hypothyroidism can include fatigue, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, hair loss, and difficulty concentrating. Women may have heavy or irregular menstrual periods. 4. Babies born to women with untreated hypothyroidism may fail to develop or function normally. Untreated hypothyroidism in children can cause physical and mental developmental delays. 5. Diagnosis of hypothyroidism involves blood tests to measure thyroid hormone levels. Treatment involves thyroid hormone replacement, which typically requires a lifelong prescription.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Hypothyroidism is caused by an underactive thyroid gland. Your thyroid gland is located in your neck, and it makes hormones that control the way every cell in your body uses energy. Hypothyroidism means your thyroid isn't making enough hormones. The most common cause is an autoimmune disorder. Other causes include thyroid surgery, radiation treatment, and inflammation. Some people are born with hypothyroidism. It develops slowly, and you might not notice anything. Symptoms include fatigue, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, and depression. You might also feel cold, have trouble concentrating, and feel anxious. If you're pregnant, you might have a miscarriage or a stillbirth. If you have heart disease, hypothyroidism can make it worse. If you have high cholesterol, it can raise your risk of heart disease.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. 2. The thyroid is a small, butterfly-shaped gland located in the front of the neck. It makes hormones that control the way every cell in the body uses energy from food. The thyroid uses iodine to make two main hormones: thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). These hormones control the way every cell in the body uses energy from food. 3. Hypothyroidism is often caused by Hashimoto's disease, an autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system attacks the thyroid. The thyroid gland may also be damaged by radiation treatment to the neck, by too much or too little iodine in the diet, or by certain medicines. 4. Symptoms of hypothyroidism include fatigue, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, and muscle cramps. A woman may have heavy periods and become infertile. Other symptoms include feeling cold, depression, memory problems, and trouble concentrating. 5. To diagnose hypothyroidism, the doctor may order blood tests to measure thyroid hormone levels. If these levels are low, the doctor may order more tests to find out the cause. 6. Treatment involves taking a pill every day that contains the correct amount of thyroid hormone. It takes time for the body to start working normally again. The doctor will check hormone levels and may adjust the dose of medicine. Most people need to take the medicine for life.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Lewy body dementia is characterized by abnormal deposits of a protein called Lewy body in the brain. This protein also leads to the formation of Parkinson's disease. People who have this disorder may experience a variety of symptoms, including:  - Changes in alertness and attention  - Hallucinations  - Muscle stiffness  - Problems with movement  - Repeated falls  - Sleep problems  - Unusual behavior  In addition, people who have Lewy body dementia may have some of the same symptoms seen in people who have Alzheimer's disease, such as:  - Decreased memory  - Difficulty performing familiar tasks  - Disorientation  - Forgetfulness  - Reduced ability to concentrate  Diagnosis  - Tests for Lewy body dementia are similar to those used for Alzheimer's disease and include neurological, psychiatric, and cognitive exams.  - Brain imaging and neuropsychological testing can help diagnose Lewy body dementia.  - A skin biopsy may be used to confirm the diagnosis, but this procedure is not always necessary.  Treatment  - No cure exists for Lewy body dementia, but medications may be used to treat some symptoms.  - The best treatment is to manage symptoms.  - A person with Lewy body dementia and his or her family members should work closely with a doctor and a nurse to manage symptoms effectively.  - People with Lewy body dementia need to avoid antipsychotic medications because these drugs may worsen some of the symptoms, such as tremors and rigidity.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Lewy body dementia, a common form of progressive dementia, is often misdiagnosed as Alzheimer’s disease or Parkinson’s disease. Technical Explanation: Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is a rare inherited disorder that affects the breakdown of certain amino acids, specifically the branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) leucine, isoleucine, and valine. 

The disease is due to mutations in the BCKDHA, BCKDHB, and DBT genes, which encode the proteins that make up the branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex. This enzyme complex is responsible for the breakdown of BCAAs in the liver. 

MSUD is characterized by feeding problems, vomiting, ketoacidosis, hypoglycemia, and neurological problems such as developmental delays and seizures. Without proper treatment, it can lead to coma and death. 

The treatment of MSUD involves a special diet, vitamin supplementation, and a medication called thiamine. The diet must be strictly controlled to ensure that the patient does not receive high amounts of the BCAAs leucine, isoleucine, and valine, which cannot be broken down in the body. With proper treatment, patients can lead relatively normal lives.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a defect in the diaphragm -- the muscle that separates the chest from the abdomen -- that allows organs from the abdomen to enter the chest cavity. CDH occurs in about one out of every 2,000 births. 2. CDH is a serious medical condition that requires immediate medical attention. The condition is present at birth, but symptoms may not be obvious until later in life. 3. CDH causes the abdominal organs to move into the chest cavity and crowd the heart and lungs. This crowding prevents the lungs from functioning properly. The condition is also called a diaphragmatic hernia. 4. A baby with CDH may have poor muscle tone or be born in breathing difficulties. The abdomen may appear bloated and the ribs may be uneven. The baby may turn blue (cyanosis) and have a rapid heart rate (tachycardia). 5. In severe cases, the baby may be unable to breathe and could die. 6. In less severe cases, a baby with CDH may be able to breathe with the help of a ventilator. The baby may need medication to help the heart and lungs work. 7. Surgery may be needed to repair the diaphragm and return the abdominal organs to the abdomen. 8. The cause of CDH was previously thought to be a genetic mutation, but this is now thought to be unlikely. Current research indicates that the most common cause of CDH is a defect in the neural crest. The neural crest is a group of cells that migrate during fetal development and form many of the body's structures, including the diaphragm. 9. CDH can be detected before birth using ultrasound and other imaging tests. In some cases, the condition may be detected using an ultrasound done for other reasons. 10. The most common complication of CDH is a hole in the lung (pneumothorax). A less common but serious complication is a narrowing of the stomach and esophagus (stricture). This complication occurs in about 10 percent of CDH babies. 1

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. A ventricular septal defect (VSD) is a defect in the ventricular septum, the wall dividing the left and right ventricles of the heart. The extent of the opening can vary from pin size to complete absence of the ventricular septum, creating one common ventricle. The ventricular septum consists of an inferior muscular and superior membranous portion. The membranous septum is an extension of the membranous portion of the interatrial septum, and the muscular septum is a continuation of the ventricular free wall. The membranous septum lies next to the right ventricle and is separated from it by the right ventricular outflow tract, which consists of the pulmonary valve, and the left and right ventricular outflow tracts. The muscular septum lies next to the left ventricle and is separated from it by the left ventricular outflow tract, which consists of the aortic valve. The right and left ventricular outflow tracts connect to the pulmonary artery and aorta respectively, and the two great arteries are connected by the ductus arteriosus. The ductus arteriosus is a blood vessel that allows blood to bypass the lungs in the fetus. The VSD is usually located at the membranous or the muscular portion of the ventricular septum. 2. Atrial septal defect (ASD) is an abnormal opening between the two atria of the heart. The most common location for an ASD is in the region of the fossa ovalis, an oval-shaped depression in the wall between the right and left atria. The superior and inferior venae cavae connect to the right atrium, and the pulmonary veins connect to the left atrium. Normally, the only exit for blood from the left atrium is the mitral valve, which leads to the left ventricle and then to the aorta for distribution throughout the body. The right atrium has two exits, the tricuspid valve leading to the right ventricle, and the pulmonary valve leading to the pulmonary artery. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the world. 2. The main cause of lung cancer is smoking. 3. People who smoke are 13 times more likely to develop lung cancer than nonsmokers. 4. Secondhand smoke can also increase the risk of lung cancer in nonsmokers. 5. Smoking marijuana cigarettes has also been linked to an increased risk of lung cancer. 6. The greatest risk of lung cancer is for those who started smoking at a young age. 7. In addition to smoking, there are other risk factors for lung cancer. 8. People who breathe in radon or who are exposed to asbestos or arsenic are at increased risk. 9. Lung cancer risk increases with age.10. Most lung cancers are diagnosed when the disease has reached an advanced stage. 11. Screening is used to identify lung cancer before symptoms appear. 12. Screening may include chest x-rays, CT scans, or PET scans.13. If a screening test shows an abnormal area in the lungs, a biopsy will be done. A biopsy is a procedure in which a small piece of lung tissue is removed. 14. Biopsy samples can be examined under a microscope to see if cancer cells are present.15. A diagnosis of lung cancer can be confirmed only by lung biopsy. 16. Once lung cancer has been diagnosed, the stage of the disease should be determined. 17. Staging is a process used to find out how far the cancer has spread. 18. A doctor will use a physical exam, blood tests, and imaging studies to determine the stage of the disease. 19. In addition to staging, doctors use what is called "tumor staging" to describe the characteristics of a particular tumor. 20. Tumor staging considers the size of the tumor, whether lymph nodes contain cancer, and whether the cancer has spread to other parts of the body. 21. There are four stages of lung cancer, and each stage is given a Roman numeral from I to IV. 22. The higher the number, the more advanced the cancer. 2
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Yes, if your husband's family has a history of lung cancer that suggests a hereditary lung cancer syndrome, genetic testing may be helpful. A genetic counselor will collect your husband's family history, including medical records and death certificates, and may perform a detailed review of the medical literature. The counselor will then discuss the likelihood that your husband's family has a hereditary lung cancer syndrome, and the risks and benefits of testing. If your husband is interested in being tested, a blood sample will be collected and sent to a genetic testing laboratory. There, scientists will look for any specific gene changes that may have caused or contributed to lung cancer in your husband's family. Testing may be done to look for changes in a specific gene, such as the EGFR gene or the KRAS gene, which are known to be involved in some hereditary lung cancer syndromes. Or testing may be done to look for all the known gene changes that might be involved in hereditary lung cancer. Testing may also be done to look for gene changes that cause other types of cancer, such as colon or breast cancer, which may be associated with an increased risk of lung cancer. Results of genetic testing may provide information about your husband's risk of developing lung cancer, and may affect decisions about screening and prevention.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive disorder which means that two copies of the gene must be affected for an individual to be affected.  In most cases, people with Friedreich ataxia inherit one copy of the gene from a parent and the other copy is from a spontaneous mutation.  The spontaneous mutation is a random event and occurs by chance.  It is possible for the spontaneous mutation to occur more than once in the same family.  When this happens, individuals are said to be "homozygous" for the disease.  When a person is homozygous for Friedreich ataxia, they are more severely affected with the disease than heterozygous individuals.  2. Friedreich ataxia affects many parts of the body, including the heart, nerves, eyes, and skeletal system.  Most people with Friedreich ataxia will develop the inability to walk (called "ataxia") by the time they reach adolescence.  They may also develop weakness in their hands and difficulty with speech and swallowing.  People with Friedreich ataxia often develop a curvature of the spine and foot deformities.  As the disease progresses, the muscles of the heart and respiratory system may weaken, making it difficult for individuals to breathe or to pump blood efficiently.  Most people with Friedreich ataxia also develop a type of diabetes called "insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM)."  Some people with Friedreich ataxia experience loss of sensation in their arms and legs (called "peripheral neuropathy"), which can result in minor cuts and bruises going unnoticed and thus becoming infected.  As people with Friedreich ataxia age, they may develop scoliosis, kyphosis, foot deformities, and cardiac complications.  3. Currently, there is no cure for Friedreich ataxia.  However, many of the symptoms and accompanying complications can be treated to help individuals maintain optimal functioning as long as possible.  Treatment for Friedreich ataxia is individualized to deal with the specific symptoms exhibited by the person with the disease.  Some of the more common symptoms treated

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 12-hour delay in the ER did contribute to her demise. Bowel ischemia is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical intervention. When diagnosed, immediate surgical intervention is usually the treatment of choice. Bowel ischemia occurs when the blood supply to the intestines is blocked or reduced, which can lead to tissue death and gangrene. The blockage can be caused by a blood clot (thrombus), an atherosclerotic plaque (fatty deposit) in an artery, or a twist or narrowing in the artery (stenosis). Bowel ischemia can result from conditions such as a heart attack, aneurysm, or abdominal aneurysm. The longer the bowel remains ischemic, the less likely it is to recover. If the ischemic segment is short, surgical resection (removal) of the affected bowel may be all that is needed. However, when the ischemic segment is long, a bypass procedure (vascular surgery) may be needed. Bowel resection and anastomosis is a surgical procedure in which a diseased section of intestine is removed and the healthy ends are reconnected. This is a common surgical procedure for bowel ischemia. In some cases, when the affected bowel is too badly damaged, a colostomy may be necessary. A colostomy is a surgical procedure in which an opening is made in the colon and the remaining bowel is diverted through it. The colostomy allows stool to exit the body through the opening. It may be temporary or permanent, depending on the severity of the disease and the healing process. In your mother's case, the surgeon had to remove most of her small intestine due to the gangrene. However, even with prompt surgical intervention, the outcome can be poor due to compromised intestinal blood supply.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Leber congenital amaurosis is a rare eye disorder that primarily affects the retina. 2. In Leber congenital amaurosis, the photoreceptors don't develop properly, and the retina doesn't function normally. 4. This results in problems with vision, including poor night vision (nyctalopia), difficulty adjusting to changes in light (photophobia), and a decrease in peripheral vision (tunnel vision). 5. The exact symptoms can vary among affected individuals. 6. In some cases, there may also be abnormalities of the eye's structure, such as an odd shape or size of the pupil (the hole in the middle of the iris). 7. In rare cases, the condition may be associated with other abnormalities, such as hearing loss or mental delays. 8. The symptoms of Leber congenital amaurosis usually appear within the first few months of life. 9. A genetic mutation in at least 11 different genes can cause this disorder, and the severity of the symptoms can vary based on which gene is affected. 10. There is currently no cure for Leber congenital amaurosis, but there are treatments that can help improve vision.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Cardiomyopathy is disease in which the heart muscle becomes weakened, stretched, or has another structural problem. 2. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is usually inherited. 6. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is generally caused by an autoimmune disease or a metabolic disorder.  7. Symptoms of cardiomyopathy depend on the type. 8. The symptoms of dilated cardiomyopathy include shortness of breath, especially during physical activity; swollen legs and abdomen; and fatigue. 9. Symptoms of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy include shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain (angina). 10. Symptoms of restrictive cardiomyopathy include fatigue and shortness of breath. 11. A diagnosis of cardiomyopathy is made by echocardiogram, which uses sound waves to make images of the heart. 12. Treatment depends on the type of cardiomyopathy. 13. Dilated cardiomyopathy is treated with medicines and lifestyle changes to reduce the workload on the heart, such as reducing fluid retention and preventing or treating heart failure. 14. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may be treated with medicines, including beta blockers, to slow down the heart rate and improve blood flow. 15. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is treated with medicines and lifestyle changes to reduce the workload on the heart, such as reducing fluid retention and preventing or treating heart failure. 16. People with cardiomyopathy should avoid vigorous physical activity and contact sports.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. You have not mentioned what type of albinism. There are various types of it.2. Albinism is a condition that affects the production of melanin, the pigment that gives color to skin, hair and eyes.3. There are several different types of albinism, some of which also affect the eyes and vision.4. Oculocutaneous albinism, the most common form of albinism, affects the production of melanin in the skin, hair and eyes.5. Hermansky-Pudlack syndrome is a rare, inherited form of albinism that primarily affects the eyes and vision. It also can cause abnormalities in the skin and hair.6. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare inherited disorder that affects the immune system and causes a low level of white blood cells. It also causes albinism and other problems.7. Albinism can be detected before or soon after birth. In infants with albinism, the skin, hair and eyes are very light. The eyes will appear very pale, and in bright light, a red reflex is visible in the eyes. As the child grows, the skin and hair may darken somewhat.8. As people with albinism age, their skin may develop freckles and moles, and their hair may gray.9. Albinism is a lifelong condition. There is no cure.

Individuals with OCA often have increased sensitivity to sun exposure due to the lack of protective melanin pigment, and may suffer from certain vision problems due to the absence of melanin in the eye. 6. In rare cases, individuals with OCA may have some areas of the skin that produce melanin. This condition is called piebaldism. 7. You can consult an Ophthalmologist for further guidance. PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: Hi, Welcome to PMC-LLaMA forum.  As you describe, you are having a rare type of albinism, as most of the people with albinism have black hair and brown eyes.  You might be having Chediak Higashi syndrome which is a rare genetic disorder, with albinism as one of its symptoms.  Other symptoms of this disorder include immune system problems, bleeding problems, and recurrent infections.  In this disorder, the body makes abnormal proteins (called lysosomal trafficking regulator proteins) that are needed for lysosomes to function normally. Lysosomes are small organelles within cells that contain substances that help fight infections and assist in the breakdown of many different types of molecules.  The abnormal protein causes lysosomes to function improperly.  As a result, the immune system and the body's ability to fight infections are impaired.  This condition usually results in early death.  The only known effective treatment is bone marrow transplantation.  Hope this answers your query. Regards

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Gastroparesis is a disorder characterized by delayed gastric emptying, which results in the inability of the stomach to properly empty its contents. Gastroparesis is a chronic condition that requires careful management to avoid complications such as malnutrition, dehydration, and bezoar formation.2. Diabetes mellitus is the most common cause of gastroparesis. Other causes include: Viral infections (eg, norovirus), medications (eg, opioids, calcium channel blockers, anticholinergics), neurologic disorders (eg, Parkinson disease, multiple sclerosis), autoimmune diseases (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma), infections (eg, botulism, spirochetal infections), and malignancy.3. The diagnosis of gastroparesis is based on the clinical picture, with upper GI symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, and early satiety, and a history of delayed gastric emptying documented by radiologic tests.4. The first line of treatment for gastroparesis is dietary modification and small, frequent meals. Medications, such as metoclopramide and domperidone, are also commonly used, but usually provide only marginal benefit.5. In cases of recurrent aspiration and bezoars, feeding bypassing the stomach can be used (eg, nasoenteric tube, gastrostomy, gastrojejunostomy). Other methods of feeding include percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy, percutaneous jejunostomy, and elective surgical gastrostomy or jejunostomy. In cases of recurrent aspiration, a feeding jejunostomy may be indicated.6. Parenteral nutrition may be indicated if the patient is unable to obtain adequate nutrition by the enteral route.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 100% of type 1 diabetics will develop complications if they live long enough. However, good control of blood glucose can delay the appearance of complications.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. The most common long-term complication of type 1 diabetes is damage to the small blood vessels and nerves. High blood glucose levels over a period of years can cause damage to the blood vessels that supply nerves. This is called diabetic neuropathy. Damaged blood vessels can't provide the nerves with the oxygen and nutrients they need to work properly. As a result, nerves can become damaged and stop working. 2. Diabetes also can damage blood vessels in the retina of the eye. This damage can lead to vision loss. 3. Diabetes also can lead to kidney damage. The kidneys can lose function and eventually stop working. This is called kidney failure. 4. Diabetes also can lead to heart disease. Heart attack and stroke are the most common causes of death in people with diabetes. 5. Nerve damage to the extremities (arms and legs) can occur. This condition is called diabetic peripheral neuropathy. 6. People with diabetes also have a greater risk of developing certain kinds of cancer. People with type 1 diabetes are more likely to develop kidney cancer and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. People with type 2 diabetes are more likely to develop liver cancer and pancreatic cancer.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: The chronic complications of type 1 diabetes develop over time. They involve damage to the small blood vessels and nerves. Diabetes can damage the small blood vessels in the retina of the eye. This can lead to vision loss. Diabetes also can damage the small blood vessels and nerves in the kidneys. This can lead to kidney failure. Diabetes also can cause problems with the small blood vessels and nerves in the feet. It can take months or years for diabetic neuropathy or diabetic retinopathy to develop. Nerve damage can cause numbness and pain in the limbs. Damage to the small blood vessels in the retina can cause loss of vision. Damage to the small blood vessels and nerves in the kidneys can lead to kidney failure. Damage to the small blood vessels in the feet can lead to loss of foot ulcers and gangrene. Gangrene is the death of tissue. It is usually caused by a lack of blood flow.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1) Nephropathy: Diabetes can damage the kidneys. The first stage is called nephropathy, or damage to the small vessels in the kidney. This stage does not cause any symptoms. The blood pressure may be normal at this point, but it is very important to protect the kidneys from further damage. Blood pressure control, using ACE inhibitors or ARBs if there is high blood pressure, is important. A low-protein diet is also important. Yearly urine microalbuminuria testing is important to see if the kidneys are leaking albumin. 2) Neuropathy: Diabetes can damage the nerves, causing pain, tingling, and/or numbness in the hands, feet, and other areas. Controlling the blood sugar and cholesterol help protect against nerve damage. 3) Retinopathy: Diabetes can damage the blood vessels in the eyes. This can lead to vision loss. Yearly eye exams are important to see if there is any damage. 4) Foot problems: Diabetes can damage the blood vessels and nerves to the feet. This can lead to loss of feeling in the feet and make it harder to notice cuts and sores. Proper foot care, including daily examinations of the feet, is important.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: The results of the study were published in the January 2014 issue of the Journal of Neuroscience.  The lead author is Dr. Albe J. Berger.  The paper can be found at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24340808.  The take home message is that a defect in a sodium channel in the nerve cells of the tongue is responsible for burning mouth syndrome.  The defect is in a sodium channel called Nav1.7.  This channel is found only in the nerve cells of the tongue.  The defect causes a continuous internal signal to be sent from the tongue to the brain. This signal is interpreted by the brain as pain. The paper shows that a drug called oxcarbazepine that is currently used to treat epilepsy and a pain disorder called trigeminal neuralgia is able to block this sodium channel and stop the signal of pain from the tongue to the brain.  The paper also shows that people who suffer from burning mouth syndrome have a high level of this sodium channel in their nerve cells of the tongue.  The next step is to take this information and start a clinical trial in people who have burning mouth syndrome.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA) is a disorder of the kidneys that occurs when the kidneys do not properly remove acids from the blood into the urine. As a result, too much acid remains in the blood (called acidosis). 2. The most common cause of dRTA is a problem with a protein in the kidney called the sodium bicarbonate cotransporter. This protein is responsible for moving sodium and bicarbonate (HCO3-) into the tubules. If this protein is defective, the kidneys cannot properly remove acid from the blood. 3. dRTA is usually present at birth (congenital). It develops during the first few years of life. Infants with dRTA often have feeding problems, slow growth, and episodes of vomiting and dehydration. 4. Other causes of dRTA include autoimmune disorders (in which the body's immune system attacks one of its own proteins), kidney stones, obstructions in the kidney, and some medications. 5. The symptoms of dRTA vary depending on the cause and severity of the condition. People with dRTA may have symptoms such as: - frequent urination - dry mouth - constipation - muscle aches and pains - bone pain - feeling tired and weak - feeling short of breath - kidney stones 6. In addition to the above symptoms, people with dRTA due to a defect in the sodium bicarbonate cotransporter may also have: - a high blood acid level (metabolic acidosis) - low blood levels of potassium and/or calcium - low blood levels of sodium and/or bicarbonate 7. Diagnosis of dRTA is based on a physical exam, a thorough medical history, and laboratory tests. The doctor may also order imaging studies and nerve tests to rule out other conditions that may cause similar symptoms. 8. Treatment of dRTA varies depending on the cause and severity of the condition. In general, people with dRTA need to take sodium bicarbonate and/or potassium citrate supplements to reduce or prevent the buildup of acid in the blood.

While LBD is not yet fully understood, researchers believe it is caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. However, no specific gene has been identified as being involved in LBD. Rather, researchers believe that LBD represents a spectrum of diseases with different genetic causes.  Heavy drinking is also thought to play a role in the onset of LBD, by contributing to the development of alpha-synuclein deposits. People with LBD often have features of other neurodegenerative disorders, such as Parkinson's or Alzheimer's. The initial warning signs of LBD are often very subtle. This condition is characterized by the presence of abnormal B cells in the blood, bone marrow, and spleen that look "hairy" under a microscope. Hairy cell leukemia affects B cells in the bone marrow, which prevents other types of white blood cells (particularly the red blood cells and platelets) from maturing and entering the bloodstream. This results in low red blood cell and platelet counts, causing fatigue and increased risk of infection and bleeding.  The goal of treatment is to reduce or eliminate the abnormal B cells and allow normal blood cells to be produced. Treatment options include chemotherapy medicines, biological therapy, and radiation therapy. Some patients may need no treatment, or only observation, if their condition is not causing symptoms or complications.  The prognosis depends on the patient's overall health, age, and stage of the cancer. In general, hairy cell leukemia is considered an indolent, or slowly progressing, cancer. With treatment, many patients can live for many years without experiencing disease symptoms.

Since the kidneys are responsible for maintaining normal electrolyte concentrations in the body, they will remain unaffected by insulin. However, since the insulin deficiency leads to high blood sugar levels, the glomerular filtration rate is increased leading to increased urine formation. Since the body is unable to maintain normal blood sugar levels, there is increased urine production which leads to heavier urine bladder.

It is caused by a variety of conditions that result in damage to upper motor neurons or their brainstem interconnections. Onset can be rapid or gradual.4. Most people with locked-in syndrome have quadriplegia (paralysis of all four limbs) and are unable to breathe without assistance. Many also have impaired cognition, affecting all aspects of language processing, including comprehension, expression, reading, and writing.5. The prevalence of this disorder is unknown. It is estimated to occur in fewer than one in a million people per year, with fewer than 5,000 cases reported worldwide.6. The treatment of locked-in syndrome focuses on the management of associated conditions, such as hypertension, hyperglycemia, and urinary tract infections. Physical therapy can help prevent contractures and improve mobility.7. The prognosis for recovery from locked-in syndrome is poor. Most people with this syndrome die within a few years due to associated medical problems or aspiration.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Cri du Chat Syndrome (CDCS) is a genetic condition caused by the absence or deletion of chromosome 5p. 2. The main clinical features are characteristic cry, developmental delay, behavioral problems, intellectual disability, and distinctive facial features. 3. The cry is described as a high-pitched, cat-like, and can be heard up to several hundred meters away. 4. The cry is more evident during the first few months of life and often improves after the first year of life. 5. Children with CDCS have characteristic facial features including a small head with widely spaced eyes, epicanthal folds, a small mouth, and a round face. 6. Developmental delay, intellectual disability, and behavioral problems are common in people with CDCS. 7. Delay in reaching developmental milestones such as sitting, walking, and talking may occur. 8. Developmental and behavioral problems may include attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and intellectual disability. 9. CDCS is diagnosed by the characteristic cry and genetic analysis of chromosome 5. 10. The cry can often be heard at birth. 11. Genetic analysis of chromosome 5 can be done after the cry is noted and the diagnosis is suspected. 12. Genetic analysis of chromosome 5 can be done with chromosome analysis or fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH). 13. There is no cure for CDCS. Treatment is supportive and aimed at the specific problems individuals with CDCS have. 14. Some individuals may benefit from medication for ADHD or ASD. 15. Individuals with CDCS are likely to have a normal life span. 16. People with CDCS are at increased risk of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), anxiety, and depression. 17. People with CDCS are also at increased risk of developmental delay, intellectual disability, and behavioral problems. 18. The cry often improves over time and may not be heard after the first year of life.

Among the 168 potential interactions, 45 are associated with significant decreases in serum concentration of one or more of the drugs, 20 are associated with significant increases, and 57 are associated with an increased risk of adverse effects. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a condition in which the heart muscle becomes thick. Often, only 1 part of the heart is thicker than the other parts. This is called asymmetric hypertrophy. 2. The heart is divided into 4 chambers. The 2 bottom chambers are called ventricles. The 2 upper chambers are called atria. HCM most often occurs in the ventricles. 3. The thickened area can be “fixed,” meaning that it will not move during the cardiac cycle, or “dynamic,” meaning that it moves with the cardiac cycle. 4. Most people with HCM have no symptoms and may never develop symptoms. Some people with HCM may experience shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain. 5. The most serious complication of HCM is sudden cardiac death due to a fatal heart rhythm disturbance. Sudden cardiac death is usually caused by a fatal heart rhythm disturbance called ventricular fibrillation. 6. To diagnose HCM, a doctor will use a medical history, physical examination, and test results. The most common test used to diagnose HCM is an echocardiogram. 7. The goals of HCM treatment are to relieve symptoms and prevent complications. Medications are often used to treat symptoms such as chest pain and shortness of breath. Beta-blockers are often used to slow down the heart rate and improve blood flow. People with HCM should avoid strenuous exercise and competitive athletics. 8. Some people with HCM may need a pacemaker or an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) to prevent sudden death. Surgery is rarely needed for HCM. 9. HCM cannot be cured, but medications and implantable devices can help control symptoms and prevent complications. People with HCM usually live normal lives. 10. The most common inherited heart condition is aortic valve disease, followed by hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). 11. The most common congenital heart defects are atrial septal defects, ventricular septal defects, and patent ductus arteriosus. 12

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1) Heart conditions are of two types - congenital (present from birth) and acquired (develop over time). 2) Congenital conditions are due to defect in development of heart during fetal life and can be diagnosed by ultrasound scans and other tests during pregnancy. 3) Acquired conditions are due to lifestyle, environment, infections etc. and may present later in life. 4) These can be diagnosed by clinical examination and investigations like ECG, Echocardiography, TMT, stress echo etc. 5) In case of acquired conditions, cause has to be treated first and then the symptoms. 6) In case of congenital conditions, no treatment may be required if mild, and surgical correction may be required in severe cases.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1) Heart conditions: There are many types of heart conditions, some of which are congenital (present from birth). Heart disease in children may also occur from problems with the heart that were present at birth, and may gradually get worse as the child grows. PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM): Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a genetic heart condition in which the heart muscle becomes abnormally thick (hypertrophied). As a result, the heart muscle has difficulty relaxing and filling with blood. Symptoms include chest pain, fatigue, dizziness, fainting, and shortness of breath. 2) Long QT Syndrome: Long QT syndrome is a group of disorders that affect the electrical functions of the heart. It is caused by defects in genes that regulate heartbeats. People with long QT syndrome have an increased risk of sudden death from an irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia). Symptoms may include dizziness or fainting after a sudden move or change in posture, or while running or exercising.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Congenital heart disease: A congenital heart defect is a problem with the structure of the heart that is present at birth. In most cases, the cause of congenital heart disease is not known. The heart is a complex organ with four valves and several chambers. It is also made up of various muscles and connections that allow the blood to flow through the heart and out to the body. A congenital heart defect is present if the heart does not function properly because of a problem with the structure of the heart. 2. Cardiomyopathy: Cardiomyopathy is a disease in which the heart muscle becomes weakened, stretched, or has another structural problem. There are three types of cardiomyopathy: Dilated cardiomyopathy, Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, Restrictive cardiomyopathy. Dilated cardiomyopathy means the heart muscle becomes weak and enlarged. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy means the heart muscle becomes thick. Restrictive cardiomyopathy means the heart muscle becomes stiff.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Williams Syndrome (also known as Williams-Beuren Syndrome or WS) is a genetic condition that is present at birth and can affect anyone. It is caused by the presence of an extra copy of a small piece of chromosome 7, which is inherited from one parent. The parents of a child with WS usually have no symptoms of the condition.  People with Williams Syndrome have unique personalities and abilities. They are friendly, outgoing, and tend to smile frequently. Many people with WS have a remarkable ability to learn music. They may also have trouble understanding concepts like time or money. People with WS often have star-like skin markings, a broad forehead, puffiness around the eyes, a short, upturned nose, and a small mouth. They may have dental problems like teeth that are small, widely spaced, crooked, or missing. Children with WS often have feeding problems as babies and young toddlers. As teenagers and adults, people with WS are likely to have trouble with their blood sugar levels and to be overweight.  Many children with WS have medical problems. The most common problem is a heart defect that needs to be treated with medicine or surgery. Children with WS can also have problems with their blood vessels, kidneys, and liver. They are more likely to get infections, especially of the ears and throat. Girls with WS often have irregular menstrual cycles and are unable to get pregnant.  Williams Syndrome is usually not inherited. If a child has WS, the parents do not have it. The condition happens when a person gets an extra copy of a small piece of chromosome 7. The extra genetic material usually comes from the mother.  There is no medication or treatment to cure Williams Syndrome. Treatment is based on the symptoms a person has. For example, glasses or contact lenses may be used to correct vision problems. A device that makes sounds when activated by a switch may help a person with hearing problems. There is no cure for the mental retardation or unusual personality of Williams Syndrome.  People with Williams Syndrome should have regular checkups with a doctor. The doctor will check for health problems that are more common in people with WS. Regular checkups can help find medical problems
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Williams Syndrome is a genetic disorder that is caused by a deletion of about 26 genes on chromosome 7. Individuals with Williams Syndrome have distinctive facial features, mild to moderate intellectual disability, and heart and blood vessel (vascular) problems.  Individuals with Williams Syndrome may also have other health problems such as diabetes, inflammation of the joints (arthritis), and digestive system problems.  Individuals with Williams Syndrome are very interested in social interactions and tend to be very friendly and outgoing. They are also very curious about the world around them. However, they can also be impulsive, anxious, and easily distracted.  Children with Williams Syndrome often have delayed speech and language development. They may also have problems with attention and memory. As adults, many individuals with Williams Syndrome have trouble holding a job.  Williams Syndrome is usually not inherited. It happens as a result of a chance event during the formation of an egg or sperm cell. Parents should not assume that their child's condition was inherited. It is important to remember that even though a condition is not inherited, genetic counseling may still be helpful. This is because there is a 1 in 2,500 chance of having another child with Williams Syndrome.

There is no cure for Williams Syndrome. Treatment is aimed at the person's symptoms. People with Williams Syndrome should get regular checkups with a health care provider.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Williams Syndrome is a developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body. It can cause problems with learning, hearing, your heart and circulatory system, and your digestive system.  Williams Syndrome is caused by a problem with a gene in the person's chromosome. It is passed down through families (inherited).  Williams Syndrome affects males and females equally. It can occur in any racial or ethnic group. About 1 in 8,000 to 1 in 10,000 people have Williams Syndrome. It is most common in Caucasian people.  Early treatment and a high level of care can help children with Williams Syndrome reach their full potential. Children should get regular checkups with a doctor who specializes in genetics. PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: Williams Syndrome (also known as Williams-Beuren Syndrome or WS) is a genetic condition that is present at birth. It is caused by a deletion in the copy of a gene called ELASTIN that each person inherits from their parents. The gene comes from both the mother and father. Most people with WS have a 2.6 million base pair deletion in their copy of the ELASTIN gene. Some people with WS have smaller deletions or other changes in the gene. People with WS usually have mild to moderate intellectual disability or learning problems. They also may have unique personality traits and distinctive facial features including a broad forehead, short nose, wide mouth, full cheeks, and a small chin. Other features include a curvature of the spine (scoliosis) and stiff joints. Some people with WS have heart and blood vessel (vascular) problems. Often, these problems are not serious. However, some people with WS have serious heart and blood vessel problems. Infants with WS often have feeding problems and slow growth. They may have trouble gaining weight, developing, or having bowel movements at a normal time. Some females with WS have genitalia that is not fully developed. Early identification and treatment of these individuals can improve their health outcomes.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Multiple sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune disease which results from destruction of myelin in the central nervous system.  Currently there are several medications that have been approved by the FDA for the treatment of multiple sclerosis.  These medications include four different forms of interferon, glatiramer acetate, and two different forms of beta interferon.  In addition, there are currently several clinical trials going on for new medications to treat multiple sclerosis.  However, at this time there is no cure for multiple sclerosis.  The goal of treatment is to stop or slow down the progression of the disease.  Unfortunately, no medication has been shown to be able to repair the damage that has already been done.  In addition, no medication has been shown to be able to cure the disease.  The goal of research is to continue to find new medications that will be able to slow down or stop the progression of multiple sclerosis.  Unfortunately, it is impossible to predict when a cure will be found.  It could be as early as next year or it could be 20 years from now.  The hope is that a cure will be found in the near future.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Multiple sclerosis is a chronic immune-mediated inflammatory disorder of the central nervous system (CNS). It is characterized by a triad of inflammation, demyelination, and gliosis (scarring); the course can be relapsing-remitting or progressive. The clinical manifestations of MS are diverse and can involve almost any neurologic function, including sensation, strength, coordination, and the ability to move and think.  The goals of treatment are to prevent relapses, to prevent disability, and to improve the patient's quality of life. Because no treatment is curative, the cornerstone of long-term management is patient education regarding the disease process, treatment options, and the importance of adherence to prescribed therapy. Therapeutic agents for MS are classified as IFN-beta, glatiramer acetate, fingolimod, teriflunomide, and natalizumab.  Treatment with the beta interferons, glatiramer acetate, fingolimod, and teriflunomide is usually administered by subcutaneous injection on a regular basis, and treatment with natalizumab is administered by intravenous infusion on a regular basis.  A cure for MS is not yet available.  However, progress is being made in the development of new medications.  Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further. Take care
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by destruction of the myelin sheath that covers nerves in the central nervous system.  The exact cause of MS is unknown. However, it is thought to be an autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system attacks the central nervous system.  There is no cure for MS, but there are treatments to help manage symptoms.  Some drugs can reduce the frequency and severity of relapses, or attacks, in people with relapsing-remitting MS.  Other drugs can help reduce the progression of disability if taken continuously for several years.  Most people with MS can live active lives with proper treatment, symptom management, and healthy lifestyle choices.  More than 100,000 people in the United States are affected by MS. The disorder is usually diagnosed between the ages of 20 and 50, with two times more women than men being affected.  No one knows what triggers the initial attack, why some people go on to develop MS, and why others do not.  However, there are several known risk factors:  Having a family member with MS Increased age Male sex MS symptoms may appear in varying patterns.  Usually, they come and go with no set pattern.  The diagnosis of MS may be made when an individual has had attacks with signs and symptoms characteristic of the disease.  In other cases, the diagnosis may be made when a person has an attack that is characteristic of MS, and at some later point, the person has another attack that leads to the diagnosis.  In still other cases, the diagnosis may be made after a person has shown symptoms characteristic of MS for at least 30 days, along with signs of damage to the central nervous system.  The following tests may be performed to help diagnose MS:  Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) Cerebrospinal fluid analysis (lumbar puncture) Evoked potential tests (visual, hearing, or electrical)  Tests of depression or cognitive dysfunction
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Multiple sclerosis is a disease characterized by the destruction of myelin, the fatty covering that insulates nerve fibers, which can cause a variety of symptoms. This destruction is caused by an autoimmune response, in which the body's immune system begins to treat myelin protein as an invader and destroys it.  There is no cure for multiple sclerosis, although new medications are being introduced that seem to have promise.  The disease is progressive, and although there are periods of remission, the disease tends to worsen over time.  It is not yet possible to reverse the damage already done to the myelin sheath, although attempts are being made to develop stem cell research to try to replace damaged cells.  The best hope at this point is to prevent the disease or stop it at an early stage, and this is where research is being focused.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Multiple sclerosis is a disease characterized by the body's immune system attacking the protective covering (myelin sheath) that surrounds the nerves. The damage to the myelin sheath interrupts the flow of information within the brain and spinal cord.  The exact cause of multiple sclerosis is unknown. However, researchers think that multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease, meaning the body's immune system attacks its own tissues.  Several factors may trigger the disease, including:  - Infection  - Trauma to the central nervous system  - Genetic factors  - Environmental factors, such as where one lives or dies  - Other autoimmune diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or rheumatoid arthritis  - Virus infection  - Vaccination  - Pregnancy  - Oral contraceptive use  - Silicone breast implants  - Physical trauma  - Psychological stress  - Epilepsy   There is no cure for multiple sclerosis. However, several medications and other treatments can help manage symptoms and prevent or lessen some problems.  People with multiple sclerosis often can benefit from working with a team of health care professionals that may include a neurologist, urologist, physical therapist, and social worker.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (scarring), and neuronal loss.  The most common course of the disease is the relapsing-remitting subtype, which is characterized by unpredictable acute attacks (relapses) followed by periods of relative remission with no new signs of disease activity (remission). The other type is progressive subtype, which is characterized by a steady functional decline from disease onset. The clinical manifestations of MS result from the involvement of the nervous system at different levels. Weakness in the extremities results from involvement of motor pathways in the brain and spinal cord. Sensory loss results from involvement of the posterior column, spinothalamic tract, and medial lemniscus. Optic nerve involvement produces visual disturbances, and bladder and bowel dysfunction results from involvement of the descending autonomic tracts. The diagnosis of MS is based on the patient's history, neurologic examination findings, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and spinal cord. MRI is sensitive to lesions in the white matter, which are often diagnostic of MS when found in typical locations.  There currently is no cure for MS.  Several medications have been approved for treatment of relapsing forms of MS. Most of these medications are given by injection either monthly or every other month. Medications are available to treat acute attacks and symptoms of MS. Several medications are available to treat the symptoms of bladder dysfunction, spasticity, and pain. Physical therapy, rehabilitation, and cognitive retraining are also important parts of the overall management of MS. Most patients with MS do not walk at 20 years after disease onset. In general, patients with MS have a normal life expectancy, although they may be at increased risk for suicide.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Lupus is an autoimmune disease that means your body’s immune system attacks healthy cells and tissues by mistake. This can damage your joints, skin, blood vessels and organs. There are many kinds of lupus. The most common type, systemic lupus erythematosus, affects many parts of the body. Discoid lupus causes a rash that doesn’t go away. Subacute cutaneous lupus causes sores after being out in the sun. Another type can be caused by medication. Neonatal lupus, which is rare, affects newborns.  Anyone can get lupus, but women are most at risk. Lupus is also more common in African American, Hispanic, Asian and Native American women. The cause of lupus is not known. Genetics and environmental factors may play a role.  Lupus has many symptoms. Some common ones are joint pain or swelling, muscle pain, fatigue, fever, chest pain, hair loss, mouth ulcers and sensitivity to the sun. There is no one test to diagnose lupus, and it may take months or even years to make the diagnosis. There is no cure for lupus, but medications and lifestyle changes can help control it.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an inherited disorder that involves progressive weakness of the muscles. It is one of nine types of muscular dystrophy. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common and most severe form of muscular dystrophy.  People with this condition have muscle weakness that quickly gets worse. They have difficulty walking, jumping, and running. The shoulder muscles are often the first to be affected. The pelvic and leg muscles follow, making it hard for children to keep up with their peers.  About 1 in 5000 boys in the United States are born with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The disease is much more common in males than females. The disease is caused by an X-linked recessive gene. This means that the defective gene that causes the disease is located on the X chromosome. Males have only one X chromosome, so they will have the disease if they inherit the defective gene. In females, the defective gene is on one of the two X chromosomes. Females who have one defective gene are said to be carriers. They usually do not have the disease.  Duchenne muscular dystrophy is usually diagnosed before age 6. Most boys reach their full growth potential by age 10. The heart and respiratory muscles are affected by age 18. The disease is usually fatal by age 25.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an inherited disorder. It follows an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance and mainly affects males.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an inherited disorder that involves progressive muscle weakness. It is the most common childhood-onset muscular dystrophy and one of the most common genetic disorders affecting all races and ethnic groups. The disease is caused by an absence of dystrophin, a protein that helps keep muscle cells intact.  A boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy is usually born appearing normal. The first signs of the disease--such as difficulty walking, frequent falls, and toe walking--usually appear during the preschool years. In most boys, the disease progresses so that by adolescence they cannot stand or walk.   Duchenne muscular dystrophy affects the muscles that move the limbs (the arms and legs), the muscles used for breathing, and the heart. The disease slowly affects the muscles used for the bladder and bowel emptying.  The most severe symptom of Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a weakening of the heart and respiratory muscles. Complications of Duchenne muscular dystrophy include cardiomyopathy (enlarged heart), scoliosis (a severe curvature of the spine), and malignant hypehermia (a potentially fatal reaction to certain medications used for general anesthesia).  Duchenne muscular dystrophy is diagnosed by a combination of the family history, a physical exam, and laboratory tests. The family history may show that many male relatives on the mother's or father's side of the family had the disease. The physical exam shows a characteristic "waddling" gait and the inability to rise from the floor without help. The muscle in the lower leg is usually too weak to lift the foot uphill, causing the child to toewalk.  Laboratory tests include a muscle biopsy, genetic tests, and an electrocardiogram (ECG). A muscle biopsy can sometimes confirm the diagnosis, but genetic testing is usually needed to confirm the diagnosis.  Duchenne muscular dystrophy is managed by a team of health care providers, including a neurologist, cardiologist, pulmonologist, physical therapist, and orthopedist. Physical therapy is an impoant
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an inherited disorder passed down through families (genetic). It is caused by an absence of dystrophin, a protein that helps keep muscle cells intact. The disease occurs almost exclusively in boys. Onset is between ages 3 and 5. The disease gets progressively worse until it causes death, usually by the third decade of life. The heart and respiratory muscles may also be affected. Treatment includes physical therapy to keep muscles working, medicines to lessen inflammation, and steroids to lessen muscle weakness.

Certainly! Here are some resources and insights to help you understand the condition better: 

1. What is the condition?

The condition is called Selective mutism. It is a childhood anxiety disorder where a child does not speak in specific social situations (usually at school) despite being capable of speech in other situations.

2. Who experiences this condition?

Children between the ages of 2 and 11 may experience selective mutism. It is more common in boys than in girls.

3. What are some of the common symptoms?

Children with selective mutism often fail to communicate verbally despite having the ability to speak. They may communicate through gestures, nodding, or writing. They may also have other signs of anxiety, such as refusing to go to school or crying.

4. How is it treated?

Treatment for selective mutism usually involves behavioral therapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy, and sometimes medication. The goal of treatment is to help the child reduce anxiety and gain the ability to speak in social situations.

5. Where can I find more information?

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. HIV/AIDS is a serious disease that weakens the immune system, making it hard for the body to fight off infections and some diseases. As a result, people with HIV/AIDS often have many different kinds of infections. 2. HIV/AIDS is caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). HIV can be transmitted through: Unprotected sex (vaginal, anal, or oral) Sharing needles or other injection drug equipment Sharing toothbrushes or razors with an infected person Receiving infected blood 3. When HIV infects a cell, it becomes a proviral DNA copy of the original HIV virus in the infected cell. The proviral DNA can remain dormant in the infected cell for years before it begins to kill the cell. 4. In the United States, more than 1.1 million people are infected with HIV, but nearly 25% of them don't know they have the disease. 5. The current standard of care for HIV/AIDS is highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART), which uses a combination of at least three drugs to fight the virus. 6. A healthy immune system can control HIV, keeping the virus at a low level in the blood (known as viral suppression). But if the immune system becomes weakened, HIV can multiply in the blood unchecked and the amount of virus in the blood (viral load) will increase. 7. If diagnosed early, HIV can be managed with medications that keep the virus at bay. But HIV can develop into acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), which is the final stage of the disease. 8. People with HIV/AIDS may have a range of symptoms, including: Skin rashes Fever Night sweats Fatigue Weight loss Swollen lymph nodes Diarrhea 9. The goal of HIV treatment is to control the virus, which helps to prevent AIDS and decrease the risk of transmitting the virus to others. 10. There is currently no cure for HIV/AIDS, but researchers are working on new therapies and vaccines. 11. People
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. HIV/AIDS treatment aims to control the virus and improve the immune system to prevent further damage to the body. 2. Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is the standard treatment for HIV/AIDS. It involves taking a combination of medications to suppress the virus. 3. The first-line therapy for HIV/AIDS includes two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), one non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI), one protease inhibitor (PI), and a low dose of ritonavir (to boost the effect of the PI). 4. The second-line therapy includes two NRTIs and one NNRTI. 5. The third-line therapy includes two NRTIs alone. 6. The most advanced treatment, called "treatment-experienced" therapy, includes people who have taken three or more antiretroviral (ARV) drugs. 7. There are also several factors to consider when selecting an HIV/AIDS treatment plan, including medication side effects, age, and pre-existing conditions. 8. Other treatment options for HIV/AIDS include investigational drugs, drug holidays, and intermittent treatment.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Lupus is a disease that can affect the whole body. Lupus can affect different organ systems and can have different symptoms. Some of the most common symptoms of lupus include joint pain, swelling in the joints, skin rashes, hair loss, feeling tired, and feeling sick.2. Lupus is an autoimmune disease, which means your body's immune system attacks healthy cells and tissue by mistake. This can damage your joints, skin, blood vessels and organs. There is no known cause of lupus, but scientists think it may be caused by a combination of genetic, environmental and hormonal factors.3. Lupus has many symptoms. Some common ones are joint pain or swelling, fever, chest pain, hair loss, skin rashes, feeling tired, and feeling sick. You could have lupus if you have 2 or more of these symptoms that last 6 months or longer, and if none of these symptoms can be explained by any other condition.4. Lupus is often difficult to diagnose. There is no one test or sign that can make or exclude a diagnosis of lupus. Instead, your doctor has to use a number of tests to help make the diagnosis.5. There is no cure for lupus, but medications can help control symptoms. People with lupus often need to see different doctors. You will probably see a rheumatologist, who specializes in lupus and other rheumatic diseases. You may also need to see other doctors, such as a dermatologist (skin specialist), ophthalmologist (eye specialist), or nephrologist (kidney specialist).6. Treatment for lupus depends on your symptoms and how severe they are. Some people with lupus only have mild symptoms. They may only need pain relievers and sunscreen to protect their skin from the sun. Others may need medications to help control their symptoms. Steroids are one type of medication that is often used.7. You may need to take steroids to help control your symptoms. Steroids are strong anti-inflammatory medications that help reduce swelling and pain. They work by changing the way your immune system works
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Lupus is an autoimmune disease, meaning that your body's immune system attacks healthy tissue. There are many kinds of lupus, but the most common type, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), affects many parts of the body.  Lupus can be mild, with symptoms that come and go. It can also be serious, causing swelling and pain in joints, skin rashes, hair loss, mouth ulcers, and sensitivity to the sun. It can affect organs such as the kidneys and heart.  The cause of lupus is not known. Lupus is most often diagnosed in women during childbearing years. It is more common in African American, Hispanic, Asian, and Native American women than in Caucasian women. There is also a higher risk among people with family members who have lupus.  Lupus is usually a chronic disease, meaning that it needs to be monitored for a long time. There is no cure, but medications and lifestyle changes can help control it.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Lupus is a chronic, inflammatory, autoimmune disease that can affect any organ system in the body. It most commonly affects the skin, joints, lungs, heart, and kidneys. 2. Lupus is often referred to as "the great imitator" because its symptoms are so varied and can be mistaken for those of so many other diseases. Lupus is typically characterized by periods of illness (flares) followed by periods of remission when there are no signs or symptoms of the disease. 3. The cause of lupus is not known. However, scientists believe that lupus occurs when a person's immune system becomes stressed and begins to attack the body's own tissues. The resulting inflammation then causes pain, swelling, and loss of function in affected parts of the body. 4. Anyone can develop lupus, but it is most common in women between the ages of 15 and 45. Women are 10 times more likely than men to develop lupus. Women who develop lupus before they reach menopause may have more severe disease than those who develop lupus later in life. 5. There is no one test for diagnosing lupus. Instead, doctors use a combination of methods to determine if the person's symptoms are caused by lupus. These methods include a physical exam, blood tests, urine tests, and imaging studies. The doctor also may perform a biopsy and measure ANTIOCH LEVELS. 6. Lupus is typically treated with medications that control inflammation, suppress the immune system, and/or match the symptoms of the disease. These medications include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), antimalarial drugs, corticosteroids, and immunosuppressant drugs. 7. People with lupus should get regular medical checkups and blood tests to monitor their disease. They should also learn as much as possible about lupus and work closely with their doctors to manage their disease.

Treatment is based on the symptoms you have.   The goals of treatment are to:  - Relieve pain and swelling  - Prevent flares  - Reduce organ damage  - Help you maintain a normal life  - Reduce the number of doctor visits and hospital stays  - Reduce the long-term effects of lupus Medicines used to treat lupus include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), antimalarial drugs, and steroids. There are also newer drugs called biologics. Most people with lupus do not need to take steroids.  People with lupus should get enough rest, avoid stress, and maintain a healthy, balanced diet.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1.2 x 2.3 mm kidney stone can be treated by medical dissolution therapy, surgical management or lithography. Medical dissolution therapy includes potassium citrate syrup or sodium bicarbonate with sodium citrate. This medication increases the urinary pH and thereby causes the stone to dissolve. This method is slow and takes 4-6 weeks to dissolve the stones. Surgical management includes PCNL (percutaneous nephrolithotomy). In this procedure, a track is created in the kidney and a hollow tube is inserted into the kidney. The stones are broken into small pieces and removed using a suction cannula. Lithotripsy is a procedure where a stone is broken into small pieces by shock waves. This requires hospitalization. The fragments are then flushed out in the urine. Hope this answers your query. If you have additional questions or follow-up queries then please do not hesitate in writing to us. I will be happy to answer your queries. Wishing you good health.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. JOCK ITCH: Chronic infection of the groin and other body folds, including the underarms. It is a fungal infection caused by dermatophytes, most often by Epidermophyton floccosum, Trichophyton rubrum, and Trichophyton mentagrophytes. Clinical presentation: Affected areas have a reddish, scaly rash with raised margins. Burrows (tunnels in the skin) may be present. The skin may be itchy and sometimes has a foul odor. The dermatophyte fungi invade the skin and form an environment that is favorable for their growth. The fungi are most often found in skin folds, such as the groin area, under the breasts, and under the arms. Risk factors: Occlusive clothing, warm and humid climate, obesity, and poor hygiene. Associated conditions: Diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, and other immunocompromised states. Other conditions that may increase the risk of jock itch include: Candidiasis (thrush), dermatitis, lichen sclerosus, lichen planus, and psoriasis. Treatment: Topical antifungal medications are usually effective. 2. Treatments with topical corticosteroids, antibiotics, and/or coal tar may be used to treat secondary bacterial infections and inflammation. Topical medications may be combined with oral medications to treat resistant infections. 3. Keep the groin area clean and dry, and wear loose-fitting clothing. Use antibacterial soap. Avoid sharing towels or razors.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a common gastrointestinal disorder. Its etiology is unknown. 2. Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a psychiatric disorder that can develop after a person is exposed to a traumatic event, such as sexual assault, warfare, traffic collisions, or other threats on a person's life. 3. PTSD is often accompanied by disturbances in the management of fear and anxiety. Symptoms may include shakiness, sweating, heart rate and blood pressure instability, irritability, and poor concentration. 4. Although the two disorders have different etiology, there are a lot of overlapping symptoms. For example, both IBS and PTSD patients may experience abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, nausea, bloating, and other non-specific gastrointestinal symptoms. 5. A lot of studies have found that patients with IBS frequently have psychiatric disorders, especially anxiety and depression. However, only a few studies have found that IBS patients have higher prevalence of PTSD compared to general population. 6. The most recent study found that the prevalence of PTSD was 10% in IBS patients, which is significantly higher than general population. 7. A possible explanation of IBS and PTSD co-occurrence is shared brain mechanisms of limbic system and hypothalamus. Another possible explanation is that the common psychosocial factors may influence the development of both disorders. 8. The main message is that IBS patients should be screened for PTSD. If PTSD is found, appropriate treatment should be offered to the patient.
