The prevalence of PTSD in IBS is higher than in the general population, and this appears to be true in both men and women with IBS.3. Patients with PTSD plus IBS have more severe symptoms and greater health care utilization than do patients with either disorder alone.4. Increased health care utilization is particularly evident in patients with PTSD plus IBS who seek medical care in emergency departments.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2:
1. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a common gastrointestinal disorder with high personal and economic costs. 2. The aetiology of IBS is still largely unknown. 3. A number of studies have investigated the relationship between IBS and psychiatric disorders. 4. This study aims to investigate the relationship between IBS and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). 5. This is a retrospective study using a validated questionnaire, which was compiled from the literature and sent to 250 patients with IBS in one gastroenterology unit in the Netherlands. 6. The questionnaire addressed demographic and clinical characteristics, co-morbidity, gastrointestinal and non-gastrointestinal symptoms, and co-morbid psychiatric disorders. 7. A total of 145 patients (58%) returned the questionnaire. Of the 145 patients, 39 (27%) reported a history of PTSD, which is significantly higher than the reported prevalence of PTSD in the general population (Odds ratio = 2.3; 95% CI = 1.4-3.7). 8. This study shows a significantly higher prevalence of PTSD in patients with IBS compared with the general population. 9. This is a retrospective study with a response rate of 58%. Patients may not have reported PTSD accurately. 10. It is unclear whether PTSD causes IBS, or whether both conditions have a common aetiology. 11. This study suggests that clinicians treating patients with IBS should be alert for a history of PTSD.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1.  Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a psychiatric disorder that can develop after a person is exposed to a traumatic event, such as sexual assault, warfare, traffic collisions, or other threats on a person's life. 2.  People with PTSD may experience negative, distressing thoughts and feelings. They may also experience certain physical symptoms, such as sweating and tachycardia (a fast heart rate). 3.  People with PTSD are at a higher risk for suicide and intentional self-harm. 4.  PTSD often develops within 6 months of the trauma, but can occur at any time. 5.  Symptoms of PTSD may last for many years, though typically (and ideally) a person can get help to manage and/or overcome their symptoms. 6.  People with PTSD are at a higher risk for other mental disorders, such as depression, and substance use disorder. 7.  The lifetime prevalence of PTSD is 8.7%, with 10% of men and 6% of women being diagnosed at any point in time. 8.  In the U.S., there are about 300,000 cases per year. 9.  There are no known cures for PTSD, but there are treatments that can help manage symptoms. 10.  Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacological treatment are the mainstay treatments of PTSD. 11.  In CBT, a person works through their trauma memory and learns coping skills to help them overcome their fear. 12.  There are also medications that can help with the management of PTSD symptoms, including selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs).

Symptoms may include disturbing thoughts, feelings, or dreams related to the events, mental or physical distress to trauma-related cues, attempts to avoid trauma-related cues, alterations in how a person thinks and feels, and an increase in the fight-or-flight response. These symptoms last for more than a month after the event. Young children are less likely to show distress, but instead may express their memories through play. 2. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a common cause of chronic abdominal pain and cramping. Although IBS can cause a great deal of discomfort, it doesn't cause any damage to the intestines. IBS is common, occurring in about 12 percent to 20 percent of the U.S. population. IBS is typically a long-term condition that tends to recur over time. Symptoms of IBS generally begin during the teen or early adult years, although it's possible to develop the condition at any age. In most people who have IBS, the abdominal pain and other symptoms are intermittent rather than constant. In IBS, the abnormalities of the bowel are only found on an elevated level of discomfort, which is the reason why IBS is also called a functional gastrointestinal disorder. 3. It is estimated that 20% to 30% of people who have PTSD also have IBS, and as many as 40% to 80% of people who have IBS have PTSD. Studies suggest that IBS is two to three times more common in people who have PTSD than in the general population. People who have PTSD and IBS are more likely to have other functional gastrointestinal disorders, such as functional dyspepsia (a "sensation" of impending heartburn) or functional constipation. 4. It is often first noticed as joint pain and swelling. Weight loss, diarrhea, and abdominal pain may occur. The heart, brain, and nerves may also be affected. A biopsy of the small intestine shows infection with PAS-positive, diastase-resistant rod-shaped bacteria. A blood test that detects antibodies to the bacteria can help diagnose the condition.  Other conditions that may lead to weight loss and joint pain must be ruled out.  The disease is treated with long-term antibiotics. Without treatment, the condition is fatal. With treatment, people usually recover. The course of the disease varies, but about 10 years after diagnosis, the disease may return.

Diagnosis is based on clinical signs and symptoms, and it is confirmed by the demonstration of low prolactin levels. 4. Since the pituitary gland is also responsible for the production of growth hormone, its deficiency can also lead to the development of adult growth hormone deficiency, which can cause a decrease in growth velocity. 5. The main consequence of this condition is the development of secondary hypertension, which is due to elevated levels of renin and other vasoactive substances.

The pituitary gland regulates the function of other endocrine glands and hormones, so the consequences of Sheehan's syndrome include failure of lactation, fatigue, hypogonadism, and hypothyroidism. 3. The diagnosis may have been missed in the past because of lack of awareness of the condition and the fact that the symptoms are very nonspecific.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1) Sheehan syndrome is a condition that results from reduced blood supply to the pituitary gland during childbirth. In severe cases, the reduced blood supply can lead to permanent damage to the pituitary gland. The pituitary gland produces hormones that control many body functions, including the production of milk in women. Reduced function of the pituitary gland can lead to problems with milk production and other hormone-related health problems. 2) Some women may not realize they have Sheehan syndrome until they try to breast-feed their baby. Others may not experience symptoms until later in life. 3) A doctor may diagnose Sheehan syndrome by measuring hormones in the blood. They may also ask about symptoms and perform a physical exam.

In people with Sheehan's syndrome, the pituitary gland does not work correctly. This can affect the production of thyroid hormones, as well as hormones that help regulate blood pressure and body temperature.5. The symptoms of Sheehan's syndrome can be mild or severe, depending on how much the pituitary gland has been affected. Mild symptoms include fatigue, low energy, and decreased libido. Obesity means having too much body fat. It is different from being overweight, which means weighing too much. The weight may come from muscle, bone, fat, and/or body water. Both terms mean that a person's weight is greater than what's considered healthy for his or her height. 

To determine if you are overweight or obese, your doctor will compare your weight with that of healthy people of the same age and gender. Your doctor may also use a measurement called a body mass index, or BMI. BMI is a measure of body fat. 

People with obesity have a high risk of developing disorders that include heart disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, arthritis, and some cancers. 

To treat obesity, you will most likely need a combination of 

1. Changing your eating habits and food choices
2. Increasing your physical activity
3. Learning new, healthy ways to deal with stressful times
4. Getting support from family and friends

Some people may also need medicines or surgery. 

To keep off excess weight, you will need to make permanent changes in your daily routine. This may mean 

1. Changing the way you eat, including eating fewer calories and less fat
2. Making sure you get 60 minutes or more of physical activity every day
3. Including strength training exercises
4. Avoiding sugary drinks
5. Learning healthy ways to deal with stressful times

Some people find it helpful to join a weight-control group. A commercial weight-loss program may also be a good choice. You may want to ask your doctor or a dietitian for help in choosing a program. 

To reduce your risk of obesity-related health problems, you should

1. Aim to keep your BMI at 18.5 to 24.9 
2. Choose a healthy diet. Foods to choose include

- Vegetables
- Fruits
- Whole grains
- Low-fat or nonfat dairy products
- Lean meats

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Esophageal cancer is cancer that starts in the esophagus. This is the tube that moves food from the mouth to the stomach. Most esophageal cancers are squamous cell carcinomas, which start in the thin, flat cells lining the esophagus. Another type of esophageal cancer is adenocarcinoma, cancer that begins in cells that make and release mucus and other fluids. Sometimes squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma occur in the same person. This is called mixed carcinoma.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Esophageal cancer is a rare form of cancer that develops in the esophagus, the hollow tube that carries food and liquids from the throat to the stomach. As a cancer, it is characterized by the uncontrolled growth of abnormal cells. There are two main types of esophageal cancer, each with two subtypes. Squamous cell carcinoma, which can develop in the upper, middle, or lower third of the esophagus. Adenocarcinoma, which can develop in the lower third of the esophagus where it meets the stomach. The symptoms of esophageal cancer depend on the location of the tumor. Tumors in the upper and middle thirds of the esophagus often cause symptoms of dysphagia (difficulty swallowing). Tumors in the lower third of the esophagus often cause symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Esophageal cancer is often diagnosed in late stages because there are few, if any, early symptoms. Regards

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Lynch syndrome is an inherited disorder that causes an increased risk of developing colon cancer and rectal cancer.  People with Lynch syndrome also have an increased risk of developing cancer of the stomach, small intestine, liver, gallbladder ducts, upper urinary tract, brain, skin and prostate.  Women with Lynch syndrome also have a high risk of developing uterine cancer (cancer of the uterus).  Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder.  This means that one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of cancer.  People with Lynch syndrome have a 50% chance of passing it to each of their children.  The condition is caused by a mutation in the MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2 or EPCAM gene.  The MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2 and EPCAM genes normally make proteins that are involved in repairing errors that occur during the replication of DNA.  These proteins fix the errors that occur when DNA copies are made during cell division.  When one of these genes is mutated, the protein it makes does not work properly.  As a result, DNA replication is more likely to have errors, and the risk of cancer increases.  Research suggests that people with Lynch syndrome who have a mutation in the EPCAM gene are at risk for developing cancer of the stomach, small intestine, and large intestine.  The EPCAM gene normally makes a protein called Ep-Cam.  Researchers think that the Ep-Cam protein may be involved in the development of cancer.  People with Lynch syndrome who have a mutation in the EPCAM gene are more likely to develop cancer of the stomach, small intestine, and large intestine.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Glaucoma is a group of diseases that can damage the eye's optic nerve and result in vision loss and blindness. The most common form of the disease is open-angle glaucoma. With early treatment, you can often protect your eyes against serious vision loss.  How It Develops  There is increased pressure in the eye. This is caused by too much fluid being made or not enough fluid draining from the eye.  The increased pressure may be due to:      Buildup of fluid in the eye. This can happen if the eye is formed abnormally, or if there is a problem with the drainage canals.  Partial blockage of the drainage canals. This can happen if the canals are narrowed by glaucoma or other eye diseases.  An increase in the amount of fluid produced in the eye. This can happen if the eye is formed abnormally or if certain medicines are taken.  There is also a rare form of glaucoma called angle-closure glaucoma. With this type, the angle in the eye where fluid leaves becomes blocked. This causes a sudden rise in pressure in the eye.  Symptoms  In the early stages of glaucoma, there are no symptoms. Later, you may have side vision (tunnel vision) and see halos around lights. Redness and pain are not common, but they can happen. Your eye may seem to have a blue or grey tint.  Diagnosis  Your doctor will use drops that dilate your pupil and look at your eye with a slit lamp. This is a type of microscope that gives a narrow view of the eye. Your doctor may also do other tests, including:  A glaucoma test that measures the pressure in the eye  A cornea mapper that measures the shape of the cornea  A slit lamp with a Placido disc to check your optic nerve  A computer-controlled scan that checks how the pupil and the cornea work together  A gonioscope to check the flow of fluid in the eye  An ophthalmoscope to check the inside of the eye  A field exam to check side vision  Your doctor may also do a nerve fiber layer measurement. This checks how much damage the optic nerve has.  Rarely, your doctor may do other

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Glaucoma is a group of diseases that can damage the eye's optic nerve and result in vision loss and blindness. The most common form of the disease is open-angle glaucoma. With early treatment, you can often protect your eyes against serious vision loss. Take the following precautions to help prevent or manage glaucoma:  Learn about glaucoma. Stay informed about glaucoma and its treatment. Ask your doctor and eye care professional questions about glaucoma.  Get regular eye check-ups. Regular eye exams are important to find glaucoma early, when it's easiest to treat. Your doctor or eye care professional will look for signs of glaucoma during a comprehensive eye exam. This includes testing your visual acuity, checking your pressure, and examining your eye.  Take your medications as prescribed. If you have glaucoma, your doctor or eye care professional will prescribe eyedrops or pills to help lower your intraocular pressure (IOP). Don't skip doses or stop taking your medicine without talking to your doctor.  Lower your intraocular pressure. To help control your intraocular pressure, you might need to make some lifestyle changes. These changes include:  - Eating a healthy diet  - Getting regular exercise  - Maintaining a healthy weight  - Avoiding stress  - Not using tobacco  - Avoiding alcohol  - Using a safer, non-toxic cleaning product

Spina bifida is a congenital condition that occurs when the neural tube, the structure that eventually becomes the spinal cord and spinal nerves, does not close completely during fetal development. Spina bifida occurs most commonly in the lumbar (lower) region of the spine, and when it occurs there, it is called spina bifida occulta. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Meesmann corneal dystrophy occurs due to a genetic defect in the production of a corneal protein called keratin-12. Keratin-12 helps to keep the outer layer of the cornea healthy. 2. As this protein is not produced properly, the outer layer of the cornea becomes weak and eventually deteriorates. 3. This causes the symptoms of blurred vision, discomfort and sensitivity to light. 4. As the condition worsens, the cornea becomes scarred and vision deteriorates even further. 5. Treatment options are as follows: 6. Epithelial debridement: The loose, dead cells on the outer layer of the cornea are removed using a fine brush or a laser. 7. Phototherapeutic keratectomy (laser keratectomy): The excimer laser is used to remove the outer layer of the cornea. This can be repeated several times until the symptoms improve. 8. Contact lenses: These can help to protect the cornea and also improve vision. 9. Corneal transplant: This is a last resort and is only recommended if the other treatments do not work. 10. PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Rubella is a viral disease that commonly causes a rash and fever. It's also called German measles. It's much less serious than measles. Most people with rubella don't have any symptoms. But, rubella is contagious and can be very serious for pregnant women. Infants born to infected mothers are at risk of developing congenital rubella syndrome. It can cause heart defects, hearing loss, cataracts, and mental retardation. Rubella is a airborne disease, spread through respiratory secretions, and also spread through contact with infected surfaces. Rubella is most contagious from about one week before the rash appears until up to one week after it disappears. Children are the most susceptible to rubella, and outbreaks occur most often in elementary schools. Adults who have been vaccinated are protected, but adults born before 1957 may have been exposed to the disease. Rubella is treated with supportive care. It's most important for pregnant women to avoid contact with people who have rubella. All children should be vaccinated against rubella.

AMD may also cause objects to appear smaller18. There may be a blind spot in the centre of vision19. In some cases, only one eye is affected, but in most cases, AMD develops slowly in both eyes20. In most cases, there is no pain or discomfort associated with the disease.21. Age-related macular degeneration is usually diagnosed by having an examination by an ophthalmologist.22. A specific test called a macular function test may be used to assess how well the macula is working.23. Treatment for Age-related macular degeneration depends on whether the disease is dry or wet.24.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Guanfacine is used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension). High blood pressure adds to the workload of the heart and arteries. If it continues for a long time, the heart and arteries may not function properly. This can damage the blood vessels of the brain, heart, and kidneys, resulting in a stroke, heart failure, or kidney failure. High blood pressure may also increase the risk of heart attacks. These problems may be less likely to occur if blood pressure is controlled.    Guanfacine works by controlling the nerve impulses along certain nerve pathways. As a result, it relaxes the blood vessels so that blood passes through them more easily. This helps to lower blood pressure.    Guanfacine extended-release tablets are also used alone or together with other medicines to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children and adolescents. It works in the treatment of ADHD by increasing attention and decreasing restlessness in children and adults who are overactive, cannot concentrate for very long, or are easily distracted and impulsive. This medicine is used as part of a treatment program to control symptoms of ADHD. Treatment with guanfacine may take 4 weeks to show the maximum benefit.    This medicine is only used to treat a specific type of ADHD called attention deficit hyperactivity disorder-irritability (irritability component of ADHD). It is not used to treat other types of ADHD.    This medicine is available only with your doctor's prescription.    This product is available in the following dosage forms: Tablet   Tablet, Extended Release

1. Guanfacine extended-release tablets can cause low blood pressure and may increase the risk of depression or suicidal thoughts. Taking guanfacine extended-release tablets may improve some of these symptoms.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. The recommended dose of Tylenol is 325 mg to 1 gram every 4 to 6 hours. 2. Peptic ulcers are caused by excessive acid production in the stomach due to a variety of factors.  One of the factors is the ingestion of aspirin.  Other factors include excessive alcohol intake, excessive caffeine intake, excessive stress, and certain foods. 3. Acid production in the stomach is controlled by the parietal cells in the stomach lining.  When parietal cells are stimulated, they produce an enzyme called cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1).  COX-1 conves arachidonic acid into prostaglandins.  Prostaglandins stimulate the parietal cells to produce even more COX-1 enzyme, thereby increasing acid production.  Aspirin inhibits COX-1 enzyme production, thereby decreasing acid production. 4. However, Tylenol does not inhibit COX-1 or COX-2 enzymes.  Therefore, Tylenol does not decrease acid production. 5. When excessive acid is produced, it can literally eat a hole through the lining of the stomach or the first part of the small intestine, thereby causing a peptic ulcer. 6. Ingestion of Tylenol causes the parietal cells to produce COX-1 enzyme, thereby increasing acid production.  Acid production can literally eat a hole through the stomach lining or small intestine, thereby causing an ulcer. 7. The ulcerative pain appears to be caused by the excessive acid production, not by Tylenol. 8. You can prevent the ulcerative pain by taking one gram of nonparticulate antacids (such as Maalox) every four hours while you are taking Tylenol. 9. You should also avoid foods that stimulate acid production, such as excessively spicy foods, excessively caffeinated foods, excessively alcoholic foods, excessively fatty foods, and excessively acidic foods (such as citrus fruits and fruit juices).

The diagnosis of Lyme Disease is based on symptoms, history of exposure to infected ticks, and blood tests to detect antibodies to the bacteria. 6. Treatment is with antibiotics, which are most effective early in the disease. Antibiotics used include penicillin, doxycycline, and ceftriaxone. PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. What is spinocerebellar ataxia type 3?  Spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 (SCA3) is a progressive, degenerative, genetic disease that affects the nervous system. The nervous system controls movement, sensation, and coordination. SCA3 causes uncoordinated, jerky muscle movements called ataxia. Symptoms of SCA3 usually begin between ages 20 and 60 years and worsen over time. Symptoms include uncoordinated speech, uncoordinated eye movements, unsteady gait (walking), and loss of sensation in the extremities (hands and feet). Other symptoms may include muscle cramps, twitches, and spasms; slowed movement; and muscle weakness. The disease can be fatal in the later stages, but some people with the condition live for many years. 2. How common is spinocerebellar ataxia type 3?  Spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 affects between 1 in 100,000 and 1 in 10,000 people. It occurs in all ethnic groups and is most common in the Caucasian population. The prevalence also varies from country to country, according to how many people carry the disease gene. 3. What causes spinocerebellar ataxia type 3?  Spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 is caused by a mutation in a gene on chromosome 14. The gene carries instructions for making a protein called ataxin-3. Researchers think that the mutation causes ataxin-3 to become toxic to cells in the brain. This stops the cells from working normally, which results in the symptoms of SCA3. 4. What are the treatments for spinocerebellar ataxia type 3?  No cure exists for spinocerebellar ataxia type 3. The goal of treatment is to reduce symptoms. Physical therapy may help people improve balance and coordination. Speech therapy and devices to help with speech and swallowing may improve communication and nutrition. In some cases, medications may help reduce muscle spasms and rigidity

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1) All patients should be started on a combination of two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) plus an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI), a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI), or a protease inhibitor (PI). 2) The most commonly used NRTIs in HIV treatment include lamivudine (3TC), emtricitabine (FTC), zidovudine (AZT), didanosine (DDl), and stavudine (d4T). 3) Commonly used NNRTIs include efavirenz (EFV), nevirapine (NVP), and delavirdine (DLV). 4) Commonly used PIs include ritonavir (V) or lopinavir (in combination with ritonavir, LPV/r), nelfinavir (NFV), amprenavir (APV), and saquinavir (SQV). 5) Commonly used INSTIs include dolutegravir (DTG) and raltegravir (RAL). 6) A baseline viral load should be obtained before starting therapy, and a follow-up viral load should be obtained three to six weeks after the therapy is initiated. 7) The goal of treatment is to reduce the viral load to <50 copies/mL. 8) The choice of which agent to use as initial therapy should be individualized based on the patient's history and medication side effect profile. 9) Specific guidelines for initiation and change of antiretroviral therapy (A) in pregnant women are available. 10) The most common side effects of antiretroviral therapy (A) include headache, fatigue, dizziness, nausea, diarrhea, and altered sense of taste.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends antiretroviral therapy (ART) for all individuals diagnosed with HIV infection, regardless of their CD4 count or clinical symptoms. 2. The goal of ART is to reduce the amount of HIV in the blood (viral load) to a level that is so low that the virus cannot be detected by a standard test. 3. People with HIV infection who maintain a viral load that is below the limit of detection, and have a CD4 count that is above a certain level (usually around 200 cells/mm3), have an HIV-infection that is considered well-controlled. 4. People with well-controlled HIV-infection are less likely to develop AIDS and less likely to transmit HIV to others. 5. When ART is taken consistently and correctly, it can reduce the risk of HIV transmission. 6. However, no medical treatment can cure HIV infection. 7. Even with ART, some HIV-infected individuals continue to shed HIV in their blood and body fluids. 8. Therefore, although HIV-positive people are not necessarily highly contagious, they should still take precautions to avoid transmitting the virus to others. 9. These precautions include practicing safer sex (using condoms and/or taking PrEP), not sharing needles or other injection drug equipment, and not donating blood, organs, or semen if they are HIV-positive. 10. People with HIV infection should inform their healthcare provider and sex partners about their HIV status. 11. People who are HIV-positive but do not have AIDS should also be aware that they can still transmit the virus to others. 12. HIV-positive people should also be aware of the symptoms of opportunistic infections (OIs) and should report any signs of OIs to their healthcare provider.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4:
I'm glad to share my thoughts with you. One of the biggest challenges in treating HIV/AIDS is getting patients into care and keeping them there. Studies show that it's hard to retain patients in care because of the stigma associated with HIV/AIDS. Many clinics don't have a trans-friendly environment. A patient may be reluctant to disclose their HIV status or reveal their gender identity for fear of discrimination. They may also fear being outed as HIV-positive by having to share a waiting room with people they don't know. 

Another issue is medication adherence. Patients may have trouble taking their meds because of fear or confusion about the regimen. They may also feel overwhelmed by the sheer number of pills they have to take. And if they're not comfortable with their provider, they may not ask questions about their meds or treatment plan. 

So what can be done to break down these barriers? Here are a few ideas:

1. Create a trans-friendly environment. This means having staff trained in working with trans patients, having private areas for patients to discuss their health issues and getting patients' preferred names and pronouns used throughout the clinic.

2. Offer transportation and childcare. Many patients need help getting to the clinic or have no one to watch the kids while they're getting treatment.

3. Provide peer support. Having someone who understands what it's like to be HIV-positive and trans-identified there to offer support and answer questions can make a big difference.

4. Explain treatment clearly. Patients need to understand why it's so important to take their medications and what the consequences of not taking them will be. They also need to know what to do if they're having trouble adhering to the regimen.

5. Provide counseling and support. Many patients are depressed and anxious about their HIV/AIDS diagnosis. They need someone to talk to about their fears and worries.

6. Make treatment as convenient as possible. This means offering evening and weekend hours, having locations in the community rather than in medical centers and making sure patients know how to get refills or talk to a doctor if they have problems.

The benefits of CPAP include improved cardiovascular function, improved oxygenation, decreased daytime sleepiness, and decreased motor vehicle accidents. 2. This study was conducted to evaluate the short-term effects of CPAP use on edema. Acute left ventricular heart failure was excluded by the presence of a third heart sound and/or pulmonary crackles. 3. The study included 15 patients (10 men, five women; mean age: 56.4 +/- 11.4 years) with a mean apnea-hypopnea index of 24.1 +/- 12.5 events/hour. Patients used a CPAP machine at home for an average of 4.4 +/- 2.5 hours per day. All patients had clinical evidence of peripheral edema at the time of study entry. 4. Patients were re-examined one day and one week after initiation of CPAP therapy. Fifteen patients had clinical evidence of peripheral edema at study entry. One day after initiation of therapy, 13 patients (86.7%) had improvement or resolution of peripheral edema. After one week of therapy, 11 patients (73.3%) had improvement or resolution of peripheral edema. 5.CPAP therapy results in short-term improvement or resolution of peripheral edema in patients with congestive heart failure and sleep apnea.

CLL is a slow-growing blood and bone marrow disease that usually occurs during or after middle age. It is rare in people younger than 40 years. 2. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Yes, older infants can get jaundice. Jaundice is a common condition in newborns and is seen in more than half of all newborns. It usually goes away on its own without treatment. However, jaundice can also occur in older infants.  Jaundice occurs when the skin and eyes become yellow. It occurs when the level of bilirubin in the blood is too high. Bilirubin is a yellow substance that is produced when red blood cells are broken down. It normally travels to the intestines where it is changed to brownish color and passes in stool. Sometimes, when too much bilirubin is made, it stays in the blood and causes jaundice.  Jaundice in older infants may occur due to liver problems, certain medications, or infections. It may also occur if the infant has a family history of a liver condition called Gilbert's syndrome.  Jaundice is treated if the bilirubin level is very high or if it is a risk for causing brain damage. Treatment options include phototherapy (light treatment), medication, or a blood transfusion.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. What is Familial Mediterranean Fever? a. Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever accompanied by inflammation of the serosal lining of various organs, including the peritoneum (the lining of the abdomen), pleura (the lining of the lungs), and synovial membranes of the joints. b. In most individuals, the first attack of FMF occurs before the age of 20. c. Between attacks, patients usually feel well, although some may have mild joint pain or swelling. d. The frequency of attacks varies greatly even within the same family. Attacks can be triggered by physical exertion, emotional stress, or infection. 2. What causes Familial Mediterranean Fever? a. FMF is a genetic condition inherited from a person's parents. Most individuals with FMF have mutations in one of two genes (MEFV or MARS) that produce proteins (named pyrin and marenostrin, respectively) that are important in controlling inflammation. b. The inflammation seen in FMF results from an abnormal overproduction of a protein called IL-1beta. This protein is part of the body's immune system, which normally protects the body from foreign invaders such as viruses or bacteria. c. The abnormal overproduction of IL-1beta is due to a defective protein called cryopyrin that is produced by the MEFV gene. Cryopyrin is found mainly at sites of inflammation in the body. d. When an inflammatory response occurs, the cryopyrin in the inflamed tissue breaks down, releasing the active form of IL-1beta. The IL-1beta then triggers the release of more inflammatory proteins and causes fever, as well as other symptoms of inflammation. e. The abnormal overproduction of IL-1beta is believed to cause FMF attacks. The symptoms of FMF are due to the inflammatory response that occurs during attacks. 3. How is Familial Mediterranean Fever diagnosed? a. There are two ways in which FMF can be diagnosed: 1) Meeting 2 of 3 criteria established by the International FMF

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Nodular goiter is a condition in which the thyroid gland becomes enlarged and develops lumps (nodules). The nodules are usually noncancerous (benign). 2. The cause of nodular goiter is usually an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism) that causes the thyroid to enlarge. The overactivity increases the demand for thyroid hormone and causes the thyroid gland to grow larger as it tries to keep up with the demand. 3. Nodular goiter is most often found during an examination of the neck or while obtaining a radiograph. It is rarely associated with symptoms. Rarely, a nodule may become cancerous. A biopsy can determine whether the nodules are cancerous. 4. Most of the time, the treatment for nodular goiter is surgical. The surgeon removes the affected lobe (hemithyroidectomy) or the entire thyroid gland (total thyroidectomy). You will need to take thyroid hormone replacement therapy for the rest of your life. 5. Nodular goiter is not life-threatening, but it may be a sign of an overactive thyroid gland.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1) Surgery is the best option for treating nodular goiters that are causing problems. But if you are not keen on surgery, then the other options include: Thyroxine hormone therapy - Thyroxine hormone therapy is a treatment option for people with nodular goiters who have an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism). The therapy involves taking a daily dose of thyroxine, a synthetic version of thyroid hormone. This treatment is usually reserved for people with hypothyroidism who also have goiters. Radioactive iodine therapy - This treatment is used to shrink the thyroid gland in people with nodular goiters. It can also be used to treat an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism). Radioactive iodine is a radioactive chemical that is taken up by the thyroid gland and can destroy abnormal thyroid cells. External beam radiation therapy - External beam radiation therapy is another treatment option for people with nodular goiters who have cancerous (malignant) thyroid nodules. The goal of this therapy is to destroy abnormal thyroid cells. Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration - This procedure is used to remove samples of cells from thyroid nodules. It may be used to diagnose the cause of a nodule or to remove (aspirate) fluid from a cystic nodule. Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration can also be used to inject a sclerosing agent into a nodule to cause it to shrink (sclerotherapy).

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1) One of the most significant advancements in the treatment of heart arrhythmias is the development of catheter ablation.  Catheter ablation is a procedure in which a thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted through an artery up to the heart.  Electrical energy (radiofrequency) is delivered through the catheter to destroy the abnormal heart tissue causing the arrhythmia.  The procedure is performed by cardiologists and electrophysiologists.  This procedure has been very successful in the treatment of supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs).  While initial results with ventricular tachycardia (VT) and atrial fibrillation (AF) have been promising, long-term follow-up studies are still pending.  Also, catheter ablation has been extremely useful in the treatment of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, a condition in which there is an abnormal electrical pathway in the heart, resulting in episodes of fast heart rate and palpitations. 2) Antiarrhythmic medications are still very important in the treatment of heart arrhythmias.  However, the use of antiarrhythmic medications has diminished due to the concern of serious side effects with these medications.  Some of the significant advancements with antiarrhythmic medications involve the development of drugs that have fewer side effects.  For example, a medication called dofetilide has been recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).  This medication is effective in the treatment of AF and has been shown to have fewer side effects than some of the older antiarrhythmic medications.  Another significant advance in the treatment of AF is the use of anticoagulation (blood thinners) in patients who are being treated with these medications.  Blood thinners are necessary because of the increased risk of stroke in patients with AF. 3) Implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) and pacemakers have been significant advancements in the treatment of heart arrhythmias.  These devices are implanted in the chest under the skin and continuously monitor the heart rhythm.  If a life-threatening arrhythmia occurs,
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1) Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) is the treatment of choice for many types of arrhythmias. 2) New catheter designs and computer-generated imaging enable physicians to locate and destroy the precise site of an arrhythmia deep within the heart muscle. 3) Intraoperative mapping of the endocardial surface of the heart has improved the success rate of RFA. 4) RFA is also used to treat some types of tachycardia. 5) Other new approaches to treating arrhythmias include implantable cardioverters and defibrillators, cardiac resynchronization therapy, and a variety of new antiarrhythmic drugs.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Hi, Welcome to PMC-LLaMA. Lupus is a chronic disease that affects the body's immune system. Normally, the immune system fights infection and disease. But in lupus, the immune system attacks the body's own cells and tissues. No one knows what causes lupus. But lupus tends to run in families. And some research shows that genetic factors may play a role. Lupus is also linked to certain viruses and to certain medications. Women are more likely to develop lupus than men, and African-Americans and Hispanics are more likely to develop lupus than Caucasians. Lupus has many symptoms. Some common ones are joint pain or swelling, muscle pain, fever, chest pain, hair loss, mouth ulcers, feeling tired, and sensitivity to the sun. There is no one test to diagnose lupus, and it may take months or even years to make the diagnosis. There is no cure for lupus, but medications and lifestyle changes can help control it. People with lupus often need to see different doctors. You may see a rheumatologist who specializes in lupus, and you may also see a primary care doctor or a specialist in another area. NIH- The National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases (NIAMS)
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Lupus is a chronic inflammatory disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, lungs, heart, and brain. It is often called "the great imitator" because its symptoms can be mistaken for many other diseases. Lupus is difficult to diagnose, and there is no single test for it. Instead, doctors put together a range of clinical tests and assessments, including blood counts, urine tests, and X-rays, along with a thorough physical exam. There is no cure for lupus, but medications and lifestyle changes can help control it.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Treatment for lupus depends on the symptoms you have and how severe they are. Some people have mild symptoms and do well with little or no treatment. Others may need medicines, including steroids and immunosuppressants.  Immunosuppressants work to damp down your immune system so it doesn't attack healthy tissues.  Most people start treatment when they first have symptoms. Later, they may need treatment again if symptoms reappear.  If you have lupus nephritis, your doctor may prescribe treatment to protect your kidneys. This might include medicines and a low-salt diet.  You should not get live vaccines, including polio, measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella (chickenpox). If you have lupus, you should discuss pregnancy with your doctor. Some medicines are safe to take during pregnancy.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Medications: Drug therapy is the mainstay of treatment. The following medications are commonly used to treat lupus: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) Antimalarial drugs (e.g., hydroxychloroquine) Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) Immunosuppressive drugs (e.g., azathioprine) Anticonvulsants (e.g., carbamazepine) Antibiotics, for infections 2. Lifestyle Changes: A healthy lifestyle can help manage your symptoms and reduce your risk for complications. The following lifestyle changes may help relieve some lupus symptoms: Maintain a healthy weight. Regular exercise. Get enough sleep. Take steps to reduce stress. Avoid exposure to the sun. Taking these steps may help prevent flares and reduce damage to your joints, skin, and organs.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Lupus is a chronic disease that can affect any part of the body, but usually attacks the joints, skin, blood vessels and lungs. Lupus also can damage the kidneys and the brain. There are many kinds of lupus. The most common type, systemic lupus erythematosus, is a chronic disease in which inflammation and damage to the body's organs and tissues occur over time. Another type of lupus is acute cutaneous lupus. This type affects the skin and does not cause damage to the internal organs. Discoid lupus is a third type in which only the skin is affected. Neonatal lupus, which occurs in newborns, is a fourth type. People with lupus are prone to a variety of symptoms. Some common ones are pain and swelling in the joints, rashes on the face or body, sensitivity to the sun, hair loss, mouth ulcers, swollen glands, and feeling tired. Lupus symptoms vary from person to person and can change over time. Some symptoms are:  Joints - Pain, swelling, or stiffness in joints or surrounding muscles. Joints may be red and/or warm. Hands - Red, painful, swollen, and warm; between the fingers, there may be painful nodules. Fingers - Decreased sensation; "pins and needles." Red, painful, swollen, and/or warm; between the digits, there may be painful nodules. Face - A "butterfly" rash with redness on the bridge of the nose and on the cheeks. It may be sensitive to sunlight. Mouth - Ulcers on the roof of the mouth; sores on the tongue or inside the cheeks; loosening of the gums; painful sensitivity to hot, cold, or sweet foods Lung - Pain with deep breaths; coughing; shortness of breath; fever; or fluid in the lungs. Heart - Chest pain or discomfort when breathing deeply or exercising; decreased ability to take in enough oxygen; fluid in the lungs. Kidneys - Pain in the back, side, or groin; changes in urine output or
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Lupus is a chronic disease that affects many parts of the body. It is an autoimmune disease, which means the body's immune system attacks the tissues and organs. 2. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Friedreich ataxia is an inherited condition, means it is genetic.2. This is an autosomal recessive condition.3. In this condition, there is expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the first intron of the Friedreich ataxia gene, which encodes frataxin.4. This expansion results in a deficiency of frataxin, which is required for normal functioning of mitochondria. 5. As a result, organs with the highest energy requirements, such as the heart and the nervous system, are affected.6. Patients present with progressive weakness, ataxia, dysarthria, and loss of vibration and position sensation in the legs.7. Optic atrophy, nystagmus, and decreased sweating are also common findings.8. The mean age of death in patients with Friedreich ataxia is 40 years.9. Presently, there is no cure for Friedreich ataxia.10. A number of medications are currently being investigated for the treatment of Friedreich ataxia. These include: I. Amifostine (WR-2721). II. Coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10). III. EPI-743. IV. Frataxin. V. Gene therapy.11. Please note that all of these are still in the stage of clinical trials.12. Friedreich ataxia does not have any specific treatment in allopatry.13. In Ayurveda, the condition can be treated by Panchakarma therapy and Rasayana.14. You can also try Yoga.

Orphan designation is given to products intended for the diagnosis/treatment/prevention of a rare disease or condition, for which there is no reasonable expectation that the cost of developing and marketing it will be recovered from the sales of that drug. 4. Currently, Ionis-FAST is being studied in a phase 2/3 clinical trial (NCT01088081). The primary outcome of this study is to determine whether Ionis-FAST significantly reduces the amount of GAA repeats in the ataxin-1 gene. Secondary outcomes include measures of neurological function. 5. It is difficult to predict when Ionis-FAST will be approved by the FDA, but if the current clinical trial shows that Ionis-FAST is effective in reducing the amount of GAA repeats in the ataxin-1 gene, then it will be considered for approval.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Pacemakers are used to treat many types of heart conditions. Bradycardia, or slow heartbeat, is one of the most common indications for a pacemaker. If your heart rate becomes too slow, not enough blood is pumped to your body and brain. You may feel very tired and short of breath. In addition, you may lose consciousness or even go into a coma. A pacemaker can correct slow heartbeats caused by a block in the electrical signals that control your heartbeat. A pacemaker is a small, batterypowered device that is implanted under the skin. It sends electrical signals to your heart to regulate your heartbeat. Pacemakers can also be used to treat problems with the electrical signals that control the contractions of your heart muscle. These problems, called arrhythmias, can occur in the heart's upper chamber, called the atria, or in its lower chamber, called the ventricles. When an arrhythmia occurs, your heart may beat too fast or too slow. It may beat irregularly, or it may not contract enough to pump blood effectively. Your heartbeat may be normal, but the electrical signals that control your heartbeat may be abnormal. Your doctor may refer you to a cardiologist if he or she suspects that you have a problem with your heartbeat. The cardiologist will perform an electrocardiogram (ECG) to diagnose the problem. If you need a pacemaker, the cardiologist will implant one.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Ultrasound examination is a non-invasive and readily available imaging modality. It is the first-line investigation for the evaluation of liver lesions and is able to detect most liver neoplasms. 2. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) enables the visualization of lesions smaller than 5 mm and has a sensitivity of 95% for the detection of liver metastases, although it may miss lesions smaller than 2 cm. 3. Computed tomography (CT) scan is also a valuable investigation. It is more sensitive than ultrasound, enabling the detection of smaller lesions, and is often used to confirm the presence of lesions detected on ultrasound. 4. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is less commonly used than CT scan but may be useful in certain circumstances, particularly if the patient has a contraindication to the use of iodinated contrast medium. 5. Positron emission tomography (PET) scan is an imaging technique that can detect lesions that are difficult to identify on other imaging investigations. It may be used to identify metastases that are too small to be detected on other imaging investigations or to identify lesions in patients with a rise in the serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) but no lesions on ultrasound or CT scan. 6. Percutaneous liver biopsy can be performed under ultrasound or CT guidance. It is the most accurate investigation for the confirmation of the diagnosis of a liver lesion but carries a risk of tumour seeding. It is mainly used when the results of the non-invasive investigations are equivocal.

1. A study was conducted to determine whether a patient education booklet increases patient knowledge about physiotherapy for ankle arthritis. The booklet was based on the results of a previous study that investigated the information needs of patients with ankle arthritis. 2. A randomized controlled trial was undertaken in which patients were allocated either to the intervention group (booklet and usual care) or to the control group (usual care only). 3. Data were collected before and after the intervention. 4. Those in the intervention group were given a booklet and were asked to complete a questionnaire after reading the booklet. 5. Patients were included if they had a diagnosis of ankle arthritis, were over 18 years of age, and could read English or Spanish. 6. The questionnaire was developed by the research team and was based on the information needs identified in the previous study. 7. Data were analyzed using paired t-tests and Wilcoxon signed-rank tests. 8. The booklet increased patients' knowledge of ankle exercises (P <.001), pain management (P =.02), and general information about ankle arthritis (P =.001). 9. Further research is needed to determine whether the use of patient education booklets increases patients' adherence to physiotherapy treatment.

Functional MRI (fMRI) measures brain activity by detecting associated changes in blood flow. While fMRI is primarily used to study brain function in healthy individuals, it may also have a role in the assessment of brain tumors. 4. Positron emission tomography (PET) scanning measures metabolic activity in the brain, and can be used to investigate the metabolism of tumors. PET scanning is most useful in the evaluation of tumors that exhibit high metabolic activity, such as gliomas. 5. Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) measures the distribution of a radioactive tracer in the brain. While SPECT is primarily used to investigate blood flow and metabolism in the brain, it may also have a role in the assessment of brain tumors.

MEG is somewhat more sensitive than EEG in detecting certain types of abnormalities, especially those located in deeper structures within the brain. 3. Evoked potential (EP) studies - EP studies are used to assess the integrity of specific pathways in the brain. For example, visual evoked potential (VEP) studies are used to assess the function of the optic nerves and the visual cortex in the occipital lobes of the brain. Similarly, brainstem auditory evoked potential (BAEP) studies are used to assess the function of the cochlea and auditory nerve, and somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP) studies are used to assess the function of the peripheral sensory system and the posterior columns of the spinal cord. 4. Transcranial Doppler ultrasound - Transcranial Doppler ultrasound is used to assess blood flow velocities in the major arteries of the brain. It can be useful in identifying patients who have abnormal intracranial blood flow, such as those with stroke. 5. Positron emission tomography (PET) - PET scanning is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that is used to assess metabolic activity in the brain. While PET scanning may be useful in some cases, it is not typically used as a first-line diagnostic procedure.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. What is locked-in syndrome?  Locked-in syndrome (LIS) is a rare neuropsychological disorder that is characterized by a complete inability to move or communicate verbally due to complete paralysis, while remaining conscious and aware of one's surroundings. 2. How is it diagnosed?  Physicians must evaluate patients for the locked-in syndrome and distinguish it from other disorders that produce quadriplegia and mutism. The following conditions may resemble the locked-in syndrome: Pupil-sparing oculomotor nerve palsy, severe cerebellar disorders, Guillain-Barre syndrome, myasthenia gravis, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, schizophrenia, and catatonia. 3. What causes it?  The cause of the locked-in syndrome is usually a small infarct (area of necrosis or tissue death due to lack of blood flow) in the ventral (front) pons, a structure in the brainstem that connects to the cerebellum. This area of the brain is responsible for controlling eye movements and vocalizations. The syndrome is usually caused by a blockage or narrowing of the basilar artery, a vessel that supplies blood to the brainstem. 4. How is it treated?  There is no cure for the locked-in syndrome, although the prognosis is better if treatment is begun soon after symptoms appear. Physical therapy may be used to help the patient perform everyday activities. Speech therapy and eye movement exercises also may be used.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1) Locked-in syndrome is a rare neuropsychological disorder, characterized by a complete inability to move or communicate verbally, while remaining conscious. This condition is often confused with coma or dementia. 2) It occurs as a result of damage to specific areas of the brain, such as the pons, which controls eye movements, and the ventral pons, which controls facial expressions. 3) Locked-in syndrome is also known as cerebromedullospinal disconnection, pseudocoma, or de-efferented state. 4) Locked-in syndrome is not a form of dementia, although it can be mistaken for it. In this condition, the patient's mental faculties remain intact, and he/she is fully aware of his/her surroundings. 5) Patients with this disorder are fully alert and awake, and they often suffer from emotional distress because they are unable to communicate with others. 6) Locked-in syndrome is caused by a lesion (injury to the brain) in the ventral pons and the basal ganglia, usually as a result of a stroke, or a gunshot wound to the brain. 7) It may also result from a disease, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), muscular dystrophy, multiple sclerosis (MS), or Guillain-Barre syndrome. 8) Treatment: Physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy are often recommended to help the patient function as much as possible.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Tourette's Syndrome (TS) is a neurological disorder characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements and vocalizations called tics. Hydrocephalus is a condition in which the fluid inside the brain is not able to flow properly.  This causes the fluid to build up in the brain, leading to pressure on structures within the brain.  Symptoms of hydrocephalus include headache, problems with balance or walking, seizures, and mental deterioration. 3. TS has not been known to directly cause Hydrocephalus. The shunt implanted to treat your Hydrocephalus can cause tics as a side effect.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. The most common cause of hydrocephalus is blockage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow within the ventricular system. This blockage can occur because of an abnormality of one or more of the four ventricular outflow channels--the two lateral ventricular outflow foramina (foramina of Luschka) and the two fouh ventricular outflow foramina (foramina of Magendie and Becker)--or because of an obstruction within the cisterna magna. 2. The likelihood of an individual developing both hydrocephalus and Tourette syndrome is entirely dependent upon the etiology of the hydrocephalus. If the cause of the hydrocephalus is an abnormality of the ventricular outflow channels or the cisterna magna, then the likelihood of the two conditions coexisting is low. If, however, the hydrocephalus is the result of a different disorder, then the likelihood of the two conditions coexisting is much higher. 3. Tics are not a factor in the development of hydrocephalus.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Tourette syndrome (also called Tourette's syndrome, Tourette's disorder, Gilles de la Tourette syndrome, GTS, or, more commonly, simply Tourette's or TS) is an inherited neuropsychiatric disorder with onset in childhood, characterized by multiple physical (motor) tics and at least one vocal (phonic) tic.  Average onset between the ages of 3 and 9 years. Males are affected about three to four times more often than females. Common associations are ADHD and OCD.  About 50% of individuals with TS experience an improvement or complete resolution of symptoms by late adolescence or adulthood. In rare cases, tics can disappear but then reemerge in later adulthood.  Hydrocephalus: An accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the ventricles of the brain that results in an abnormal dilation of the ventricles. The disorder can be caused by an overproduction of CSF, by obstruction of CSF flow, by deficient absorption of CSF, or by a combination of these factors. Treatment depends on the underlying cause of the disorder and may include surgery, medication, or both.  Although the symptoms of TS and hydrocephalus are very different, there is some evidence that suggests a possible biological link between the two.  In a study published in the Journal of Child Neurology (1999, volume 14, pages 273-276), researchers found that 43 percent of children with TS also had some degree of hydrocephalus. This is significantly higher than the estimated incidence of hydrocephalus in the general population.  The researchers concluded that this association may support the notion that TS and hydrocephalus may share a common biological mechanism. More research is needed to further understand this possible connection.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. The probability of having both conditions is very low. 2. Head and neck tics associated with Tourette syndrome are unlikely to be a contributing factor to the development of hydrocephalus.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. The treatment of small cell lung cancer depends on the stage of the disease. In general, people with earlier stage disease (stage I and II) are more likely to be cured than those with later stage disease (stage III and IV). 2. Treatment of small cell lung cancer usually involves a combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Newer targeted agents, such as the tyrosine kinase inhibitors, are also being used in the treatment of this disease. 3. The most common chemotherapy regimen used to treat small cell lung cancer includes the drugs etoposide, cisplatin, and vinblastine. Other combinations may be used as well. Radiation is given as a short course of treatment for those with localized disease, or as a palliative treatment for those with advanced disease. 4. Targeted agents like tyrosine kinase inhibitors (gefitinib, erlotinib) are used as a single agent or in combination with chemotherapy for advanced disease. In patients who have relapsed after chemotherapy, other drugs like docetaxel, paclitaxel and gemcitabine may be tried. 5. New drugs like vemurafenib, dabrafenib, trametinib are being used for specific genetic mutations in NSCLC. These are called "targeted therapies". They are only given to people whose tumors have specific genetic changes or mutations. 6. These drugs, including erlotinib and gefitinib, block the growth of lung cancer cells by interfering with a specific protein (called the epidermal growth factor receptor or EGFR) on the surface of lung cancer cells.  EGFR inhibitors are approved for use in patients whose lung cancer has spread or come back after surgery, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy.  An additional new development in lung cancer treatment is a type of drug called a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, such as imatinib or sunitinib.  These drugs, which are also called targeted therapy drugs, block specific proteins inside cancer cells that promote their growth and survival.  Tyrosine kinase inhibitors are approved for use in patients whose lung cancer has spread or come back after surgery, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy. This drug, approved for use with a type of chemotherapy called paclitaxel, blocks a protein called VEGF, which helps new blood vessels form in cancer cells.  Bevacizumab is approved for use in patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Dizziness and imbalance are the most common symptoms that may be helped by hyperbaric oxygen treatment.2. The ear is not a major site of gas use in the body, but the inner ear is sensitive to changes in pressure.3. When pressure changes suddenly, as in diving, flying, or compression in the ear canal (by blowing or swimming), gas in the inner ear is displaced and dizziness and loss of balance result.4. The symptoms of Meniere's disease are thought to be caused by excessive fluid retention in the inner ear.5. Hyperbaric oxygen treatment may be helpful in treating the condition, as the increased pressure may shrink the excess tissue and reduce fluid retention.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Meniere's disease is a disorder that affects the inner ear. 2. The goal of hyperbaric oxygen therapy is to reduce the swelling of the inner ear that causes dizziness and other symptoms of Meniere's disease. 3. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy involves placing the person in a chamber that delivers pure oxygen. The person breathes this oxygen while the pressure in the chamber is changed to greater than normal atmospheric pressure. 4. The increased pressure causes more oxygen to be forced into the tissues of the body. This increased oxygen flow is believed to reduce swelling and promote healing. 5. The increased oxygen also may help reduce the formation of free radicals that can cause damage to the inner ear. 6. Some studies have shown that hyperbaric oxygen therapy can reduce the frequency of attacks and severity of symptoms in patients with Meniere's disease. However, more research is needed to understand how this therapy works and whether it is an effective treatment for Meniere's disease. 7. The National Institutes of Health recommends that patients consider hyperbaric oxygen therapy only if medicines and diet and water restrictions do not help enough.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. The objective of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of adjuvant hyperbaric oxygen therapy in the treatment of idiopathic Meniere's disease. 2. A total of 70 patients with a mean age of 41.7 years (range 22-64 years) and a mean duration of illness of 7.5 years (range 1 month to 20 years) were included in the study. 3. Patients were randomly assigned to receive 40 hyperbaric oxygen treatments (2 sessions per week for 2 months) either as a monotherapy or combined with intratympanic gentamicin. 4. The treatment protocol was well tolerated and no serious side effects were reported. 5. Statistical analysis revealed a significant improvement in the dizziness score of the control group compared to the beginning of the treatment (p < 0.001). 6. The dizziness score of the patients receiving hyperbaric oxygen monotherapy was significantly better compared to the patients receiving combined treatment (p < 0.05). 7. The results of our study suggest that adjuvant hyperbaric oxygen therapy is effective in the treatment of idiopathic Meniere's disease.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Meniere's disease is the idiopathic syndrome of fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo, and aural fullness. It affects 10-15 per 1000 people and has a prevalence of 0.5-1% in general practice. 2. The pathophysiology is poorly understood. Current evidence indicates that the condition is due to raised intracranial pressure, which is transmitted to the labyrinth via the cochlear aqueduct. 3. In addition to symptomatic treatment, several surgical procedures have been devised, all of which aim to reduce the intracranial pressure. These include the placement of a lumbar peritoneal shunt, coicostomy, and endolymphatic sac decompression. 4. These procedures have been associated with significant complications and variable success rates. 5. Another approach is to reduce the pressure in the external auditory canal and thus in the labyrinth by compressing the jugular veins. The pressure differential between the outside and inside of the labyrinth then reduces, which should theoretically help to relieve symptoms. 6. The first description of the use of hyperbaric oxygen in the treatment of Meniere's disease was by Turner in 1961. Since then, several studies have been reported, which have included patients with either unilateral or bilateral symptoms and with a varying degree of disability. 7. The treatment consists of a compression/decompression schedule, with the patient breathing 100% oxygen at pressures between 1.3 atmospheres absolute (ata) and 1.7 ata. The treatment is given in a monoplace (single-person) chamber and is administered on an out-patient basis. 8. The decompression period is particularly important. During this time, the differential pressure between the inside and outside of the labyrinth is at its maximum, and this is when the benefit of the treatment is thought to be achieved. The total treatment time is 70 min and the treatment is given twice a week for 3-4 weeks. 9. A number of different studies have been reported, all of which have shown a significant improvement in both the symptomatology and the hearing level. 10

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. What is strabismus? Strabismus is a condition where the eyes are not properly aligned and point in different directions. One eye turns in, out, up, or down while the other eye looks straight ahead. This can happen because the eye muscles are weak or too tight. It can also happen because the brain is sending mixed signals to the eye muscles. The brain tells the eyes to focus on different objects at the same time. When this happens, the eyes are not pointed in the same direction. A child with strabismus may cross his/her eyes or squint. They may also tilt their head to one side to help them see better. Strabismus can be a problem in adults too. It can affect vision and cause headaches and other problems. 2. What causes strabismus in adults? Strabismus in adults may be caused by conditions such as cataracts, diabetes, stroke or other brain disorders, and eye injuries. It may also be caused by problems with the bones of the eyes or with the nerves that control eye muscles. Sometimes, the cause of strabismus in adults cannot be found. 3. How is strabismus treated in adults? Treatment for strabismus in adults may include: Glasses or contact lenses to correct vision problems that cause eye strain Eye exercises, patching, or prism lenses to improve vision and prevent the eyes from crossing Vision therapy, which uses exercises to retrain the brain to control the eyes' movements Eye muscle surgery to correct the eye muscle imbalance that causes strabismus 4. What is the prognosis for strabismus in adults? The prognosis for strabismus in adults is generally good. Most adults respond well to vision therapy and/or eye muscle surgery. The best results usually occur when treatment is started early, before the patient has serious eye problems or a lazy eye.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Lazy eye or amblyopia is a vision problem that occurs when the brain does not properly interpret the signals sent from one eye to the brain. 2. The brain is trained to see with both eyes. 3. If one eye has poorer vision than the other, the brain will begin to rely more on the clearer vision eye. 4. This process is called suppression. 5. Suppression is a natural process that helps the brain ignore the blurrier image from one eye. 6. The goal of amblyopia treatment is to reverse this process and re-train the brain to see with both eyes. 7. Traditional amblyopia treatment involves patching the "good" eye and forcing the "lazy" eye to work harder. 8. Patching the good eye means covering it so that only the lazy eye sees. 9. This forces the brain to rely on the lazy eye for vision. 10. The brain then begins to re-train and the vision in the lazy eye improves. 11. This process can take several months or even years. 12. Adult stem cell research has identified the cellular and molecular bases of visual functions in the brain. 13. This will lead to new approaches to treat amblyopia by retraining the brain.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. What is a lazy eye? A lazy eye is an eye that has reduced or no vision because the eye muscles do not work together properly. One cause of this problem is strabismus, a misalignment of the eyes. In strabismus, the eyes are not parallel. One eye turns in, out, up, or down while the other eye looks straight at a target. 2. Treatment of mild alcohol withdrawal syndrome: The patient is often treated on an outpatient basis, unless other medical or psychiatric problems require inpatient treatment. Patients presenting in mild alcohol withdrawal may be treated on an outpatient basis, if no underlying conditions require inpatient treatment. Inpatient treatment is often indicated for patients who have coexisting medical or psychiatric conditions, who have a history of severe withdrawal reactions, or who have a high level of alcohol consumption. The treatment of mild alcohol withdrawal is generally supportive and includes adequate hydration, nutrition, and rest. In patients with mild alcohol withdrawal, sedatives are often not necessary, unless the patient is experiencing significant anxiety or insomnia. The use of sedatives for patients with mild symptoms should be carefully monitored, since they may cause respiratory depression and/or produce a "rebound" syndrome with severe withdrawal symptoms, including seizures. The treatment of mild alcohol withdrawal syndrome generally does not require the use of sedative-hypnotic drugs such as benzodiazepines. However, the use of sedatives for patients with mild symptoms should be carefully monitored, since they may cause respiratory depression and/or produce a "rebound" syndrome with severe withdrawal symptoms, including seizures. 2. Treatment of moderate/severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome: Patients presenting with moderate/severe symptoms or with complications (e.g., seizures) require inpatient treatment and consideration of ICU admission. The use of sedative-hypnotic drugs such as benzodiazepines is the mainstay of treatment. Although any benzodiazepine may be used, the authors recommend a regimen of chlordiazepoxide (orally, if oral route is available; otherwise IV diazepam or lorazepam is recommended), with the dosing depending upon the severity of symptoms. For patients whose symptoms are not severe, the authors recommend initiating treatment with 20-40 mg of chlordiazepoxide every 2-4 hours, as needed, until the patient is calm.

1. Yes, the uveitis is an autoimmune disease.2. Uveitis is a common, painful, blinding, and costly disease that affects millions of people worldwide.3. It is the most common form of ocular inflammation and the most common cause of visual loss in the working-age population.4. Uveitis is an autoimmune inflammation of the eye that may affect the iris, ciliary body, and choroid.5. The most common form of uveitis is anterior uveitis, which affects the iris and/or ciliary body.6. The second most common form of uveitis is intermediate uveitis, which affects the pars plana and peripheral retina.7. Posterior uveitis affects the choroid and is the least common form of uveitis.8. Uveitis may be a feature of an autoimmune process such as sarcoidosis, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Behcet disease, and Kawasaki disease.9. In children, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JRA) is the most common association, while in adults, the most common association is with the seronegative spondyloarthropathies.10. Uveitis may also be a complication of penetrating trauma and it may also occur after intraocular surgery.11. It has been reported following the use of drugs such as rifampin, sulfonamides, and ethambutol and also following the use of cosmetics.12. Uveitis may be a presentation of infectious diseases such as herpes simplex virus (HSV), herpes zoster virus (HZV), varicella-zoster virus (VZV), and syphilis.13. Uveitis may also be a presentation of systemic infections such as tuberculosis, brucellosis, and leptospirosis.14. Uveitis may be idiopathic.

Cogan's syndrome is characterized by interstitial keratitis and vestibuloauditory symptoms and is believed to be an autoimmune disorder. 9. 1. Identify the type of insect: If you're not sure what type of insect is invading your home, take a sample to your local Cooperative Extension Service, and they can identify the type of insect and recommend a treatment.

2. Eliminate the insect's food source: Many types of insects will feed on your pantry items, so store all your food in airtight containers.

3. Seal off the insect's hiding places: This includes your garbage cans, recycling bins, and any other containers that may attract insects.

4. Vacuum and dust regularly: Vacuum your carpets, rugs, and furniture at least once a week. Dust your furniture and other surfaces with an insecticide every month.

5. Use sticky traps: Sticky traps are an old-fashioned, yet effective, way to control insects. Placing them along walls and in closets can help catch insects before they multiply. 

6. Use chemical treatments: If you've tried everything else and the insects keep coming back, it's time to call in the big guns - insecticides. There are several types available, including foggers, sprays, and bombs. 

7. Consider hiring a professional: If you've tried everything and you just can't seem to get rid of the insects, it might be time to call in the professionals.

The penis, which is the male sex organ, is composed of the shaft (the cylindrical body), the head (glans), and the coronal sulcus (a groove on the head of the penis).

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Medications: Medications commonly used to treat anxiety disorders include benzodiazepines, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), buspirone, and beta blockers. Benzodiazepines can help relieve symptoms of anxiety quickly, but they are habit-forming and can cause dependence if used for more than a few weeks. Benzodiazepines also can cause sedation and cognitive impairment. SSRIs are effective in treating anxiety disorders and are the current first-line treatment for most anxiety disorders. The starting dose of an SSRI is usually the lowest dose on the lower end of the dose range, with gradual increases if needed. Buspirone is another option that is effective for generalized anxiety disorder. It is not habit-forming and does not cause dependence. Buspirone takes more time to work than benzodiazepines, and may not be effective for panic disorder or other anxiety disorders. 2. Psychotherapy: Two types of psychotherapy are commonly used for anxiety. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) focuses on identifying and changing negative thoughts and behaviors that lead to anxiety. It is the current treatment of choice for most anxiety disorders. The goal of CBT is for the patient to learn to manage anxiety through relaxation techniques and other coping mechanisms. Supportive-expressive psychotherapy focuses on expressing and exploring feelings and emotional conflicts that contribute to anxiety. It may help patients with anxiety disorders that are related to unresolved childhood issues or other severe anxiety disorders. 3. Other treatments: Complementary and alternative treatments such as acupuncture, herbal medicine, and meditation have not been proven to be effective in treating anxiety disorders.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Sarcopenia is defined as the decline in muscle mass that occurs with aging. 2. A decline in muscle mass may result in an associated decline in physical function. 4. Exercise is the most effective way to counteract sarcopenia. 5. Resistance training is the most effective means to increase muscle mass. 6. Exercises should be done 3 to 4 times per week, with each session lasting 20 to 45 minutes. 7. Exercises should include aerobic activity, resistance training, and stretching. 8. Exercises should be individualized and can be done at any time of day. 9. Other modalities of exercise that have been shown to increase muscle mass include progressive resistance training, heavy-resistance exercise, and isometric exercise. 10. In addition to resistance training, older individuals should increase their protein intake, particularly their consumption of milk and dairy products.

Exercise may also improve balance, coordination, and flexibility, which may reduce the risk of falls and related injuries.4. Although more research is needed to clarify the role of nutritional supplements, creatine and testosterone appear to hold promise in helping older adults build muscle strength.
