PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1) The Genetic Testing Registry (GTR) provides information about the genetic tests available for Osteogenesis Imperfecta and Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome. The intended audience for the GTR is health care providers and researchers. Patients and consumers with specific questions about a genetic test should contact a health care provider or a genetics professional. 2) Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones that break easily. It is one of a family of diseases that are collectively called collagen disorders because they are caused by problems in the collagen gene. 3) Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is a group of rare inherited disorders that affect the body's connective tissues. Connective tissues are the fibers that provide the framework for your body, support your organs and give your body structure. EDS is caused by defects in the genes that make collagen, a protein that provides the strength and flexibility of connective tissues. There are several types of EDS, which are distinguished by the types of collagen affected and the resulting connective tissue problems.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1) There is no specific test available to diagnose Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS).  Diagnosis is based on the clinical findings (history and physical examination).  Laboratory tests are done to evaluate possible causes of the symptoms, such as collagen biochemical tests, skin biopsy, DNA mutation analysis, or other tests to evaluate connective tissue disorders.  The tests may be done on blood, other body fluids, or tissue samples. 2) The symptoms of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome vary greatly from one person to another and within the same family.  Many people with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome have skin that is either too elastic or too fragile.  The skin may be hyperextensible, meaning it can be stretched too far, or it may heal poorly after an injury or surgery, leaving a scar.  Other common symptoms include joints that are too flexible and/or easily dislocated, scoliosis, or a long, thin body.  People with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome may also have dental problems, such as your teeth being either small or large, or having a malocclusion (bad bite). 3) Symptoms of Osteogenesis Imperfecta:  The symptoms of OI can vary greatly from one person to another.  The most common symptoms include:  - Fragile bones that break easily.  - Blue or brown opaque bands or patches in the cornea of the eye.  - Deafness.  - Dentinogenesis imperfecta (genetic disorder of the teeth), which causes teeth to break easily.  - Joint laxity (hyperextensibility).  4) Genetic testing for both EDS and Osteogenesis Imperfecta can be done by either full sequencing of the relevant gene or by FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization) or PCR (polymerase chain reaction) to detect specific mutations.  Both procedures are expensive and the costs are usually not covered by medical insurance.  You can contact the Genetic Testing Registry (http://www.genetest.org/) for information on testing for EDS and Osteogenesis Imperfecta.  The registries website should be able to

These may include infection, bleeding, scarring, and cataracts. 4. There are several types of eye muscle surgery. The type used will depend on your eye problem. 5. Common types of surgery include: 6. - Recession: This is the most common type of eye muscle surgery. In this procedure, the muscle is weakened or repositioned. This causes the eye to move back into place. 7. - Resection: This is the removal of a piece of the eye muscle. This weakens the muscle and causes the eye to move into place. 8. -Transposition: This involves moving an eye muscle so that it pulls on the eye differently. This may help correct eye alignment. 9. -Tenotomy: This involves cutting a piece of the eye muscle. This weakens the muscle and causes the eye to move into place. 10. The surgery is done using local anesthesia, which means you are awake but numb from the waist down. You will also get a sedative to help you relax. 11. Most people can go home the same day. You will need someone to drive you home after the surgery. 12. It will take a few weeks for your eye to heal and adjust. You should be able to see almost immediately, although your vision may be blurred for a few days. 13. It is important to have follow-up visits after surgery. These will probably include visits with the eye doctor and a plastic surgeon. Your eye doctor may also send you to a physical therapist, who will work with you to help your eye muscles move correctly.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. GERD is caused by a reflux of acid from the stomach into the esophagus.2. Avoid medications that may increase the risk of GERD, such as nitrates and calcium channel blockers.15. The esophagus has a series of small sphincters that are meant to keep stomach acid in the stomach. If these sphincters do not function properly, stomach acid can back up into the esophagus.16. If symptoms persist despite lifestyle changes and medications, surgical intervention may be warranted.17. Your doctor may recommend an endoscopy to assess the damage to the lining of the esophagus and to determine the effectiveness of your current treatment plan.18. Nonpharmacologic interventions include exercise, education, and psychosocial support. 3) Pharmacologic interventions include the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroids, and diseasemodifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). The newest DMARD, the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors, have been shown to be effective in reducing the signs and symptoms of RA. The TNF inhibitors include etanercept, infliximab, and adalimumab. 4) There are also newer biologic agents that target other inflammatory mediators in RA, such as interleukin (IL)-1 and IL-6. The anti-malarials, hydroxychloroquine and, to a lesser extent, chloroquine, are frequently used as first-line drugs for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. 4. PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: The management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) has changed significantly over the past decade. Before 2000, the main treatment approach was based on the concept of "irreversible joint damage" caused by the disease. Consequently, treatment focused mainly on relieving pain and reducing inflammation with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroids, and diseasemodifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). The goal of this approach was to limit the damage caused by the disease.  Today, we have a much better understanding of RA and know that irreversible joint damage occurs within the first 2 years of disease. Moreover, we know that early and aggressive treatment can actually prevent joint damage and disability. Consequently, the goals of treatment have changed. Today, the aim is to achieve remission or low disease activity by combining different treatment approaches.  Treatment is usually stepped up from NSAIDs to DMARDs and/or biologicals. The choice of drug depends on the patient's characteristics, disease severity, and response to previous treatments. For example, methotrexate is the first DMARD of choice, particularly in patients with risk factors for developing RA (such as positive rheumatoid factor, high CRP, or erosions on hand and/or wrist X-rays). If methotrexate fails to achieve remission or low disease activity, another DMARD (such as sulfasalazine) should be tried.  Biologicals (such as tumour necrosis factor [TNF] inhibitors) are reserved for patients with a poor prognosis (such as those with high levels of disease activity, positive rheumatoid factor, or erosions on X-rays).  Drug combinations are usually used when monotherapy with a DMARD or biological fails to achieve remission or low disease activity. The most frequently used combination is methotrexate plus a TNF inhibitor.  Treatment should also include measures to prevent osteoporosis (such as calcium and vitamin D supplements) and physical therapy (to prevent joint contractures and muscle atrophy).  Patients with RA should receive

Introduction: Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disease characterized by progressive ataxia, dysarthria, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and cardiomyopathy. Patients often present in the first or second decade of life, and the disease is invariably fatal, with death usually occurring by the fifth decade because of cardiorespiratory compromise. Friedreich ataxia is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the gene encoding frataxin (FXN). Frataxin is a mitochondrial protein that plays a critical role in iron metabolism. 2. Summary: A novel pharmacological chaperone, namely, 4-phenylbutyrate (PB), has recently been identified as a potential therapy for Friedreich ataxia. 3. Description: The first pharmacological chaperone to be identified, PB enhances the residual function of the misfolded protein, frataxin, leading to significant improvements in the cellular function of the protein. In this article, we review the preclinical development of PB as a potential therapy for Friedreich ataxia, with a focus on its mechanism of action and the results of the clinical trials conducted thus far. 4. Outlook: PB is currently undergoing a phase II/III clinical trial. Data from this trial will determine whether PB can become the first disease-modifying therapy for Friedreich ataxia.

A number of genes in this pathway have been implicated in skin cancer, including PTCH (patched), SMO (smoothened), and GLI1 (a mediator of Sonic hedgehog signaling). 2. TP53: A tumor suppressor gene that is involved in many aspects of cell growth and survival. 3. CDKN2A: This gene encodes two tumor suppressor proteins, p16INK4a and p14ARF. These proteins inhibit cell cycle progression at the G1 checkpoint. 4. MC1R: A member of the immunoglobulin superfamily that is expressed on melanocytes and binds to the secreted protein MSH. The binding of MSH to MC1R results in the activation of a signaling pathway that increases melanocyte survival and proliferation. 5. MSH2/MSH6: These genes encode proteins that are involved in the repair of DNA mismatches. 6. EGFR: This receptor is a member of the ErbB family of receptors, which also includes HER2/neu, HER3, and HER4. EGFR is involved in cell proliferation, survival, and differentiation. 7. HRAS: A member of the RAS family of oncogenes, which also includes KRAS and NRAS. RAS proteins are involved in signal transduction and cell cycle progression. 8. BRAF: A member of the RAF family of serine/threonine protein kinases, which also includes ARAF and CRAF. RAF proteins are involved in signal transduction, specifically in the MAPK pathway. 9. PLAUR: This gene encodes urokinase-type plasminogen activator. Increased expression of this gene has been implicated in invasiveness and metastasis. 10. p53: A tumor suppressor gene that is involved in many aspects of cell growth and survival.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Diabetes means your blood glucose, or blood sugar, levels are too high. With type 1 diabetes, your pancreas does not make insulin. Over time, high blood glucose can lead to serious problems with your heart, eyes, kidneys, nerves, and gums and teeth.

Glaucoma is a condition in which there is damage to the optic nerve. The damage is caused by increased pressure inside the eye. This increased pressure inside the eye is the result of fluid pressure inside the eye pushing against the back of the eye.  There are different types of glaucoma. Some are due to problems with the clear fluid that nourishes the eye (aqueous humor). This type of glaucoma is called wide-angle glaucoma. Some are due to problems with narrowing of the angle between the clear fluid chamber and the drainage chamber. This narrowing of the angle causes a sudden increase in fluid pressure inside the eye. This type of glaucoma is called angle-closure glaucoma.  Glaucoma can also be caused by trauma to the eye, inflammation, or cataract surgery.  Glaucoma can run in families. If a family member has glaucoma, you are at greater risk of developing glaucoma.  Glaucoma can develop at any age. However, people over 40 years of age are at greater risk of developing glaucoma.  Glaucoma is treated with eye drops, pills, laser surgery, and traditional eye surgery. The choice of treatment depends on the type of glaucoma, the severity of the disease, and other medical conditions like diabetes.  Some people are at risk of developing glaucoma. These people should visit an eye doctor regularly. The risk factors include:  - A family history of glaucoma  - Being over 40 years of age  - High blood pressure  - Diabetes  - A history of eye injury  - Cataract surgery  - Other eye conditions like diabetic retinopathy, chronic iridocyclitis, or macular degeneration  - Systemic conditions like heart disease, thyroid disease, and sleep apnea  - Race (Glaucoma is more common in African Americans than other races)  - Vision problems  - Narrow angles or crowded optic nerve head  - High int

There are also congenital, secondary, and juvenile types of glaucoma.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 70-80% of the small intestine is removed due to a condition called necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). NEC is a life-threatening condition that occurs when bacteria invade the intestines, causing tissue death and inflammation. NEC is most common in premature infants, though it can affect people of any age.  Premature infants, especially those born before 32 weeks of pregnancy, are at highest risk. The earlier a baby is born, the higher the risk. Risk also goes up if a baby has a low birth weight or was delivered by C-section. Adults who have other health problems, such as heart disease or diabetes, are also at risk. NEC can quickly lead to complications such as infection, blood poisoning, and perforation, which can be life-threatening.  Symptoms of NEC include loss of appetite, abdominal swelling, bloody stools, and fever. Because these symptoms can also be caused by other conditions, it can be hard to diagnose NEC. Doctors may use x-rays, abdominal ultrasounds, and blood tests to diagnose NEC. Treatment includes medications to fight infection, and in severe cases, surgery to remove the affected part of the intestine.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia is characterized by short stature, short neck, short trunk, and platyspondyly (i.e., flattened vertebrae). Clinical manifestations of spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia appear in early childhood. At birth, the affected infant may be normal in both size and appearance. The disorder is genetically heterogeneous, with at least 3 forms: X-linked, Type II, and Type III. X-linked spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia is due to mutations in the COL2A1 gene, resulting in abnormalities in type II collagen. Type II and Type III spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia are due to mutations in the COL1A1 and COL1A2 genes, resulting in abnormalities in type I collagen. 2. Metatropic dysplasia is characterized by mild to severe dwarfism, with normal growth occurring until the age of 2 years, followed by rapid deceleration to below-normal height by age 4 years. Clinical manifestations include kyphoscoliosis, small chest, and short limbs. Metatropic dysplasia is genetically heterogeneous, with both autosomal-recessive and dominant forms. The autosomal-recessive form is due to mutations in the ENPP1 gene, resulting in deficiency of diphosphate nucleotidase. The dominant form is due to mutations in the FGFR3 gene, resulting in dwarfism due to abnormal endochondral bone formation. 3. Prenatal differentiation of these disorders is possible by assessing the biochemical levels of the specific enzymes involved. For example, elevated levels of type II collagen can be identified in the amniotic fluid of affected fetuses at risk for X-linked spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 4 stages of congestive heart failure: Stage A: Patients who have the potential to develop heart failure but who do not yet have the signs or symptoms of the disease.  Stage B: Patients with existing heart disease who have not yet developed any signs or symptoms of heart failure.  Stage C: Patients with existing heart disease who have developed initial signs or symptoms of heart failure, but who do not yet have clear evidence of the disease.  Stage D: Patients with existing heart disease who have clear evidence of heart failure. Additional factors are used to determine the stage:  - Ejection fraction (the amount of blood pumped from the heart with each contraction)  - Blood pressure  - Signs and symptoms of heart failure  - Other health conditions present

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Carpal tunnel syndrome: The carpal tunnel is a narrow passageway of ligament and bones at the base of the hand. The median nerve passes through this area and can become compressed, causing pain, weakness, and tingling. Carpal tunnel syndrome is one of the most common nerve entrapments of the upper extremity. It is most often caused by repetitive stress, although it can occur from trauma, inflammation, swelling, or a space-occupying lesion. Treatment includes rest, ice, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and splinting. If symptoms persist, then a nerve conduction study should be performed. Treatment options include steroid injections and surgical release. 2. Ulnar tunnel syndrome: The ulnar tunnel is the area where the ulnar nerve travels from the elbow to the hand. The ulnar nerve supplies sensation to the small finger and half of the ring finger. Symptoms include pain, numbness, and tingling in the small finger and ring finger. Babies with Russell-Silver syndrome have a low birth weight and often fail to grow and gain weight at the expected rate (failure to thrive). They may also have a small head and body, a relatively large forehead, a triangular-shaped face, and a small, low-set jaw. Russell-Silver syndrome is also associated with a high rate of miscarriage and stillbirths. Other features of Russell-Silver syndrome may include the following: Microcephaly (an unusually small head circumference) Clinodactyly (a curving, or bending, of the fifth finger toward the hand) in about half of affected individuals Low muscle tone (hypotonia) at birth that can progress to spasticity Micrognathia (an unusually small jaw) Intellectual disability, including learning disabilities Behavioral problems: ADHD, autism, and depression 3. CAUSE: The cause of Russell-Silver syndrome is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a genetic change or mutation. Most cases of Russell-Silver syndrome are not inherited. In rare cases, Russell-Silver syndrome may be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Electric stimulation may be used alone or in combination with other treatments such as physical therapy, exercise, and medication. 2) Electric stimulation is thought to work by stimulating large nerve fibers which lessens the perception of pain and promotes the release of endorphins (natural pain killers). 3) Electric stimulation can be administered by several methods including: a) Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) - Electrodes are placed on the skin near the painful area and a small electric current is delivered to the nerves. b) Percutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (PENS) - Fine needles are placed directly into the muscle and electrical current is delivered. c) Spinal cord stimulation - Electrodes are surgically implanted in the spinal cord and connected to a pulse generator that is placed under the skin. It is not typically used for acute pain. 5) Electric stimulation has been shown to be effective in the treatment of low back pain, neck pain, and shoulder pain. It has also been shown to be effective in the treatment of neuropathic pain such as that caused by diabetic neuropathy, shingles, and sciatica. PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Primary, autosomal recessive, or familial microcephaly is a rare disorder of neurogenic brain development with a pattern of inheritance consistent with autosomal recessive transmission. 2. The clinical features are a small head and underdeveloped brain with accompanying severe neurologic impairment.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Autosomal Recessive Primary Microcephaly (MCPH) is a genetically heterogeneous disorder with several causative genes identified so far, including MCPH1, WDR62, CDKN1B, CEP152, PHC1, PHC2, CEP63, CENPJ and PARL.  Recently, mutations in PARL were found to be associated with primary microcephaly.  PARL encodes a protein that is crucial for centrosome formation and function.  Patients with PARL mutations present with primary microcephaly, intellectual disability, mild dysmorphism (including short stature, microcephaly, flat forehead, mild ptosis, short philtrum, thin upper lip, and short fourth metacarpals), and onset of seizures in early childhood.  The disease has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.  The disease is caused by a defect of the protein encoded by the PARL gene. The protein encoded by this gene is involved in the formation and function of centrosomes.  Mutations in this gene are associated with primary microcephaly and primary pachygyria.  Inherited mutations in the PARL gene have been observed in individuals with autosomal recessive primary microcephaly.  Inherited mutations in the PARL gene are observed in a significant number of patients with autosomal recessive primary microcephaly.  Mutations in this gene are associated with primary microcephaly and primary pachygyria.  Recessive mutations in PARL cause primary microcephaly.  Mutations in the PARL gene cause primary microcephaly.  Autosomal Recessive Primary Microcephaly: This is a genetically heterogeneous disorder with several causative genes identified so far, including MCPH1, WDR62, CDKN1B, CEP152, PHC1, PHC2, CEP63, CENPJ and PARL.  Recently, mutations in PARL were found to be associated with primary microcephaly.  PARL encodes a protein that is crucial for centrosome

To date, there are no reported patients with ARM in the United States.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. VDRL is a screening test for syphilis. It is a non-specific test, i.e. it can be positive in many other conditions also.2. A positive VDRL test needs to be confirmed by specific tests like FTA-ABS or TPHA.3. In case the test is positive, you need to consult your physician regarding further management.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. VDRL positive patients should be given a thorough clinical examination to ascertain the presence or absence of neurological and ocular manifestations of syphilis. 2. All patients with a positive VDRL test should be told that they have a positive test but that does not mean that they have syphilis. 3. All patients with a positive VDRL test should be told to visit a physician who can order and interpret additional diagnostic tests to determine whether they have syphilis. 4. Patients with a positive VDRL test should be given information about syphilis and be advised to avoid sexual contact until they have been treated or tested further and can be assured that they are free of infection. 5. Patients with a positive VDRL test should be advised to have repeat testing at 3 and 6 months after the initial test to ensure that their test is negative. 6. Patients with a positive VDRL test should be given information about the benefits of and the procedures for getting treatment for syphilis.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. VDRL positive does not always mean that you are suffering from syphilis. VDRL test measures antibodies that are produced by your body in response to the infection. 2. The test can be positive for 1-2 years after you have been infected. 3. You should take care to avoid spreading the infection to others. 4. Your sexual partner(s) must also be tested and treated if necessary. 5. Use condoms during sex until you both have been treated and retested. 6. If you are treated for syphilis, then you must be retested 6-12 months later. 7. Your treatment may need to be repeated if you are still positive. 8. You must let your doctor know if you have been treated previously for syphilis. 9. If you are a woman who is pregnant or might become pregnant, tell your doctor right away. 10. Avoid alcohol during treatment.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. VDRL positive patient need to confirm the result by RPR test. 2. If RPR is also positive, then the patient needs to be confirmed as syphilis positive by either: a. Specific treponemal test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, TPI) b. Specific non-treponemal test (RPR). 3. Patient should also be tested for HIV as it is common to find sexually transmitted diseases in HIV positive patients. 4. Confirmed syphilis positive patients should be treated with penicillin or one of the alternative medicines (e.g. tetracycline or erythromycin). 5. Patient should be advised to avoid sexual contact till he/she is declared cured of syphilis. 6. Patient should be advised to undergo a repeat test (RPR or VDRL) for syphilis after 6 months of treatment to confirm that the infection has been cured. 7. If the infection has not been cured, patient should be treated for a second time. 8. All sexual partners of the patient should be traced and treated even if they do not have symptoms of the disease.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. The VDRL test is a nonspecific test for syphilis and indicates the presence of antibodies that react with certain cardiolipin antigens. It is used as a screening test for syphilis and as an indicator of the response to therapy. False-positive results may occur in a variety of other conditions, including some viral infections, non-specific rheumatic disorders, and old age. A positive (reactive) VDRL test should always be confirmed with a specific test for syphilis such as the FTA-ABS. 2. A positive (reactive) VDRL test should always be confirmed with a specific test for syphilis such as the FTA-ABS. 3. In addition, the VDRL test can be used to estimate the so-called "workers' risk" of acquiring syphilis, by testing unvaccinated health care workers who may have been exposed to the disease through their work. A positive test result indicates that the individual has been exposed to the T pallidum and therefore needs treatment to prevent the development of clinical syphilis. 4. False-positive results may occur in a variety of other conditions, including some viral infections, non-specific rheumatic disorders, and old age.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1) The VDRL test is a nontreponemal serological test for syphilis. 2) A reactive (positive) VDRL test needs to be confirmed by another serological test for syphilis, such as RPR or FTA-ABS. 3) Patients with a reactive VDRL test should be considered for treatment for syphilis unless adequate treatment can be documented within the past year. 4) Patients with a reactive VDRL test should be instructed to inform sexual partners and should be given information regarding syphilis and the importance of treating asymptomatic sexual partners.

If you have MRSA, stay away from crowded areas.7. If you are a healthcare worker, wear gloves and wash your hands regularly.8. Contact your local health department if you think you have MRSA.9. PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1)Blood test: A blood test can check for MRSA bacteria in the bloodstream. 2) Chest x-ray: A chest x-ray can be used to look for pneumonia caused by MRSA. 3) CT scan: A CT scan can be used to look for pneumonia caused by MRSA. 4) MRI scan: An MRI scan can be used to look for deep-seated infections caused by MRSA. 5) Tests on cough: A sample of sputum can be checked for MRSA.
